who thus, alarm’d, to great tydides cried:
“o friend!

said to diomed, “diomed, son of tydeus, man after my own heart, i

two chiefs of force immense i see,
dreadful they come, and bend their rage on thee:

see two heroes speeding towards you, both of them men of might

lo the brave heir of old lycaon’s line,

the one a skilful archer, pandarus son of lycaon, the other,

and great æneas, sprung from race divine!

aeneas, whose sire is anchises, while his mother is venus.

enough is given to fame.

mount

ascend thy car!

the chariot and let us retreat.
do not, i pray you, press so

and save a life, the bulwark of our war.

furiously forward, or you may get killed.

”

”

at this the hero cast a gloomy look,
fix’d on the chief with scorn; and thus he spoke:

diomed looked angrily at him and answered: “talk not of flight,

“me dost thou bid to shun the coming fight?

for i shall not listen to you: i am of a race that knows neither

me wouldst thou move to base, inglorious flight?
know, ’tis not honest in my soul to fear,
nor was tydides born to tremble here.

flight nor fear, and my limbs are as yet unwearied.

i hate the cumbrous chariot’s slow advance,

i am in no

and the long distance of the flying lance;
but while my nerves are strong, my force entire,
thus front the foe, and emulate my sire.

mind to mount, but will go against them even as i am; pallas

nor shall yon steeds, that fierce to fight convey

minerva bids me be afraid of no man, and even though one of them

those threatening heroes, bear them both away;
one chief at least beneath this arm shall die;

escape, their steeds shall not take both back again.

so pallas tells me, and forbids to fly.

i say

but if she dooms, and if no god withstand,

further, and lay my saying to your heart—if minerva sees fit to

that both shall fall by one victorious hand,
then heed my words: my horses here detain,

vouchsafe me the glory of killing both, stay your horses here and

swift to æneas’ empty seat proceed,

the best that e’er on earth’s broad surface run,

move under the sun.

hence great anchises stole a breed unknown,

to aeneas.

these, were the rich immortal prize our own,
through the wide world should make our glory known.

we shall win great glory if we can take them.

”

thus while they spoke, the foe came furious on,

and stern lycaon’s warlike race begun:

“prince, thou art met.

“great and mighty

though late in vain assail’d,

so i will now try with my spear.

”

”

he said, then shook the ponderous lance, and flung;

“mistaken vaunter!

”

(diomed replied;)
thy dart has erred, and now my spear be tried;

but diomed all undismayed made answer, “you have missed, not hit,

ye ’scape not both; one, headlong from his car,

and before you two see the end of this matter one or other of you

with hostile blood shall glut the god of war.

shall glut tough-shielded mars with his blood.

”

”

he spoke, and rising hurl’d his forceful dart,
which, driven by pallas, pierced a vital part;
full in his face it enter’d, and betwixt

the nose and eye-ball the proud lycian fix’d;

pandarus’s nose near the eye.

crash’d all his jaws, and cleft the tongue within,

it went crashing in among his white

till the bright point look’d out beneath the chin.

coming out under his chin, and his glistening armour rang

headlong he falls, his helmet knocks the ground:
earth groans beneath him, and his arms resound;

rattling round him as he fell heavily to the ground.

the starting coursers tremble with affright;

the horses

the soul indignant seeks the realms of night.

started aside for fear, and he was reft of life and strength.

to guard his slaughter’d friend, æneas flies,

his spear extending where the carcase lies;

fearing lest the achaeans should carry off the body.

watchful he wheels, protects it every way,

he bestrode

as the grim lion stalks around his prey.

and follow’d where tydides swept the plain.

meanwhile (his conquest ravished from his eyes)
the raging chief in chase of venus flies:
no goddess she, commission’d to the field,

now the son of tydeus was in pursuit of the cyprian goddess,

like pallas dreadful with her sable shield,
or fierce bellona thundering at the wall,

while flames ascend, and mighty ruins fall;
he knew soft combats suit the tender dame,

new to the field, and still a foe to fame.
through breaking ranks his furious course he bends,

and at the goddess his broad lance extends;

through her bright veil the daring weapon drove,

of her delicate hand.

the ambrosial veil which all the graces wove;

the point tore through the ambrosial robe

her snowy hand the razing steel profaned,
and the transparent skin with crimson stain’d,

which the graces had woven for her, and pierced the skin between

from the clear vein a stream immortal flow’d,

her wrist and the palm of her hand, so that the immortal blood,

such stream as issues from a wounded god;[148]
pure emanation!

or ichor, that flows in the veins of the blessed gods, came

uncorrupted flood!
unlike our gross, diseased, terrestrial blood:
(for not the bread of man their life sustains,

pouring from the wound; for the gods do not eat bread nor drink

nor wine’s inflaming juice supplies their veins:)

wine, hence they have no blood such as ours, and are immortal.

with tender shrieks the goddess fill’d the place,
and dropp’d her offspring from her weak embrace.

venus screamed aloud, and let her son fall, but phoebus apollo

him phœbus took: he casts a cloud around

the field of combat is no scene for thee:

war and battle alone, can you not be contented with beguiling

go, let thy own soft sex employ thy care,

silly women?

go, lull the coward, or delude the fair.

if you meddle with fighting you will get what will

taught by this stroke renounce the war’s alarms,
and learn to tremble at the name of arms.

make you shudder at the very name of war.

”
tydides thus.

”

the goddess, seized with dread,

dione then: “thy wrongs with patience bear,

and share those griefs inferior powers must share:

we

unnumber’d woes mankind from us sustain,

dwellers in olympus have to put up with much at the hands of men,

and men with woes afflict the gods again.

and we lay much suffering on one another.

the mighty mars in mortal fetters bound,[149]

mars had to suffer when

and lodged in brazen dungeons underground,

otus and ephialtes, children of aloeus, bound him in cruel bonds,

full thirteen moons imprison’d roar’d in vain;

so that he lay thirteen months imprisoned in a vessel of bronze.

otus and ephialtes held the chain:
perhaps had perish’d had not hermes’ care

the imperial partner of the heavenly reign;

was not of mortal mould.

and greece and troy with clashing shields engaged.

another’s breasts, hewing each other’s round shields and light
hide-covered targets.

meantime on ilion’s tower apollo stood,
and calling mars, thus urged the raging god:

then phoebus apollo said to mars, “mars,

“stern power of arms, by whom the mighty fall;
who bathest in blood, and shakest the embattled wall,
rise in thy wrath!

mars, bane of men, blood-stained stormer of cities, can you not

to hell’s abhorr’d abodes

go to this man, the son of tydeus, who would now fight even with

despatch yon greek, and vindicate the gods.

father jove, and draw him out of the battle?

first rosy venus felt his brutal rage;

he first went up to

me next he charged, and dares all heaven engage:

the cyprian and wounded her in the hand near her wrist, and

the wretch would brave high heaven’s immortal sire,
his triple thunder, and his bolts of fire.

afterwards sprang upon me too, as though he were a god.

”

the god of battle issues on the plain,

he then took his seat on the top of pergamus, while murderous

stirs all the ranks, and fires the trojan train;

enraged to troy’s retiring chiefs he cried:

in the likeness of fleet acamas chief of the thracians.

“how long, ye sons of priam!

“sons of

will ye fly,

priam,” said he, “how long will you let your people be thus

and unrevenged see priam’s people die?

slaughtered by the achaeans?

still unresisted shall the foe destroy,

would you wait till they are at the

and stretch the slaughter to the gates of troy?

walls of troy?

lo, brave æneas sinks beneath his wound,

aeneas the son of anchises has fallen, he whom we
held in as high honour as hector himself.

not godlike hector more in arms renown’d:

help me, then, to

haste all, and take the generous warrior’s part.

rescue our brave comrade from the stress of the fight.
”

he said;—new courage swell’d each hero’s heart.

with these words he put heart and soul into them all.

sarpedon first his ardent soul express’d,

then
sarpedon rebuked hector very sternly.

and, turn’d to hector, these bold words address’d:

“hector,” said he, “where

“say, chief, is all thy ancient valour lost?

is your prowess now?

where are thy threats, and where thy glorious boast,

you used to say that though you had neither

that propp’d alone by priam’s race should stand
troy’s sacred walls, nor need a foreign hand?
now, now thy country calls her wonted friends,

people nor allies you could hold the town alone with your

and the proud vaunt in just derision ends.

brothers and brothers-in-law.

remote they stand while alien troops engage,

i see not one of them here; they

like trembling hounds before the lion’s rage.

cower as hounds before a lion; it is we, your allies, who bear
the brunt of the battle.

far distant hence i held my wide command,

i have come from afar, even from lycia

where foaming xanthus laves the lycian land;

and the banks of the river xanthus, where i have left my wife, my

with ample wealth (the wish of mortals) bless’d,
a beauteous wife, and infant at her breast;

infant son, and much wealth to tempt whoever is needy;

with those i left whatever dear could be:

nevertheless, i head my lycian soldiers and stand my ground

greece, if she conquers, nothing wins from me;
yet first in fight my lycian bands i cheer,
and long to meet this mighty man ye fear;

against any who would fight me though i have nothing here for the

while hector idle stands, nor bids the brave

achaeans to plunder, while you look on, without even bidding your

their wives, their infants, and their altars save.
haste, warrior, haste!

men stand firm in defence of their wives.

preserve thy threaten’d state,

see that you fall not

or one vast burst of all-involving fate

into the hands of your foes as men caught in the meshes of a net,

full o’er your towers shall fall, and sweep away

and they sack your fair city forthwith.

sons, sires, and wives, an undistinguish’d prey.

keep this before your

rouse all thy trojans, urge thy aids to fight;
these claim thy thoughts by day, thy watch by night;

mind night and day, and beseech the captains of your allies to

with force incessant the brave greeks oppose;

hold on without flinching, and thus put away their reproaches

such cares thy friends deserve, and such thy foes.

from you.

”

”

stung to the heart the generous hector hears,
but just reproof with decent silence bears.

so spoke sarpedon, and hector smarted under his words.

from his proud car the prince impetuous springs,

he sprang

on earth he leaps, his brazen armour rings.

from his chariot clad in his suit of armour, and went about among

two shining spears are brandish’d in his hands;
thus arm’d, he animates his drooping bands,
revives their ardour, turns their steps from flight,

the host brandishing his two spears, exhorting the men to fight

and wakes anew the dying flames of fight.

and raising the terrible cry of battle.

they turn, they stand; the greeks their fury dare,

then they rallied and
again faced the achaeans, but the argives stood compact and firm,

condense their powers, and wait the growing war.

and were not driven back.

as when, on ceres’ sacred floor, the swain

as the breezes sport with the chaff
upon some goodly threshing-floor, when men are winnowing—while

spreads the wide fan to clear the golden grain,
and the light chaff, before the breezes borne,
ascends in clouds from off the heapy corn;
the grey dust, rising with collected winds,

yellow ceres blows with the wind to sift the chaff from the

drives o’er the barn, and whitens all the hinds:

grain, and the chaff-heaps grow whiter and whiter—even so did the

so white with dust the grecian host appears,
from trampling steeds, and thundering charioteers.

achaeans whiten in the dust which the horses’ hoofs raised to the

the dusky clouds from labour’d earth arise,

firmament of heaven, as their drivers turned them back to battle,

and roll in smoking volumes to the skies.

and they bore down with might upon the foe.

mars hovers o’er them with his sable shield,

fierce mars, to help

and adds new horrors to the darken’d field:
pleased with his charge, and ardent to fulfil,

the trojans, covered them in a veil of darkness, and went about

in troy’s defence, apollo’s heavenly will:

everywhere among them, inasmuch as phoebus apollo had told him

soon as from fight the blue-eyed maid retires,

that when he saw pallas minerva leave the fray he was to put

helping the danaans.

sanctuary, and filled his heart with valour, whereon he took his

alive, unharm’d, with all his peers around,

place among his comrades, who were overjoyed at seeing him alive,

erect he stood, and vigorous from his wound:
inquiries none they made; the dreadful day
no pause of words admits, no dull delay;

sound, and of a good courage; but they could not ask him how it

by mars and by strife, who raged insatiably in their midst.

fearless of the fury and onset of the trojans.

serenely dreadful, and as fix’d as fate.
so when the embattled clouds in dark array,

when now the north his boisterous rage has spent,

and peaceful sleeps the liquid element:

“ye greeks, be men!

among them and exhorted them.

and catch from breast to breast the noble fire!

yourselves like brave men, and shun dishonour in one another’s

on valour’s side the odds of combat lie,

eyes amid the stress of battle.

the brave live glorious, or lamented die;
the wretch who trembles in the field of fame,

they that shun dishonour more

meets death, and worse than death, eternal shame!

often live than get killed, but they that fly save neither life

nor name.

shield.

that he dared not stay; great, brave and valiant though he was,

they drove him from them and he was beaten back.

of peace?

far other

jove got such heroes as my sire, whose soul
no fear could daunt, nor earth nor hell control.
troy felt his arm, and yon proud ramparts stand
raised on the ruins of his vengeful hand:

was hercules, my own brave and lion-hearted father, who came here

for the horses of laomedon, and though he had six ships only, and

he left the town a wide-deserted plain.

the carnage juno from the skies survey’d,

“oh, sight accursed!

now when the goddess juno saw the argives thus falling, she said

shall faithless troy prevail,

to minerva, “alas, daughter of aegis-bearing jove, unweariable,

and shall our promise to our people fail?
how vain the word to menelaus given
by jove’s great daughter and the queen of heaven,
beneath his arms that priam’s towers should fall,

the promise we made menelaus that he should not return till he

if warring gods for ever guard the wall!

had sacked the city of ilius will be of no effect if we let mars

mars, red with slaughter, aids our hated foes:

rage thus furiously.

haste, let us arm, and force with force oppose!

let us go into the fray at once.

”

”

she spoke; minerva burns to meet the war:

minerva did not gainsay her.

dire, black, tremendous!
round the margin roll’d,
a fringe of serpents hissing guards the gold:

about her shoulders, wreathed round with rout as with a fringe,

here all the terrors of grim war appear,
here rages force, here tremble flight and fear,

and on it were strife, and strength, and panic whose blood runs

here storm’d contention, and here fury frown’d,

cold; moreover there was the head of the dread monster gorgon,

and the dire orb portentous gorgon crown’d.

proud tyrants humbles, and whole hosts o’erturns.

quells the ranks of heroes who have displeased her.

swift at the scourge the ethereal coursers fly,

juno lashed

while the smooth chariot cuts the liquid sky.
heaven’s gates spontaneous open to the powers,[155]

the horses on, and the gates of heaven bellowed as they flew open

the sun’s bright portals and the skies command,

the fiery steeds, and thus to jove complains:

horses, and spoke to jove the son of saturn, lord of all.

“o sire!

“father

can no resentment touch thy soul?
can mars rebel, and does no thunder roll?
what lawless rage on yon forbidden plain,

jove,” said she, “are you not angry with mars for these high

what rash destruction!

doings?

and what heroes slain!

how great and goodly a host of the achaeans he has

venus, and phœbus with the dreadful bow,

destroyed to my great grief, and without either right or reason,

smile on the slaughter, and enjoy my woe.

while the cyprian and apollo are enjoying it all at their ease

mad, furious power!

and setting this unrighteous madman on to do further mischief.

whose unrelenting mind

i

no god can govern, and no justice bind.
say, mighty father!
shall we scourge this pride,

hope, father jove, that you will not be angry if i hit mars hard,

and drive from fight the impetuous homicide?

and chase him out of the battle.

”

”

to whom assenting, thus the thunderer said:
“go!
and the great minerva be thy aid.
to tame the monster-god minerva knows,

and jove answered, “set minerva on to him, for she punishes him

and oft afflicts his brutal breast with woes.

more often than any one else does.

”

”

he said; saturnia, ardent to obey,

juno did as he had said.

lash’d her white steeds along the aerial way.

she lashed her horses, and they flew

swift down the steep of heaven the chariot rolls,
between the expanded earth and starry poles.

forward nothing loth midway betwixt earth and sky.

far as a shepherd, from some point on high,[157]

as far as a

o’er the wide main extends his boundless eye,

man can see when he looks out upon the sea from some high beacon,

through such a space of air, with thundering sound,

so far can the loud-neighing horses of the gods spring at a

at every leap the immortal coursers bound

single bound.

troy now they reach’d and touch’d those banks divine,
where silver simois and scamander join.

when they reached troy and the place where its two

flowing streams simois and scamander meet, there juno stayed them

of air condensed a vapour circumfused:

and took them from the chariot.

for these, impregnate with celestial dew,

she hid them in a thick cloud,

on simois’ brink ambrosial herbage grew.

and simois made ambrosia spring up for them to eat; the two

thence to relieve the fainting argive throng,

goddesses then went on, flying like turtledoves in their
eagerness to help the argives.

smooth as the sailing doves they glide along.

when they came to the part where

the best and bravest of the grecian band

the bravest and most in number were gathered about mighty diomed,

(a warlike circle) round tydides stand.
such was their look as lions bathed in blood,
or foaming boars, the terror of the wood.

fighting like lions or wild boars of great strength and

heaven’s empress mingles with the mortal crowd,

endurance, there juno stood still and raised a shout like that of

together.

to your race a shame,

“argives,” she cried; “shame on cowardly creatures,

brave in semblance only; as long as achilles was fighting, if his

once from the walls your timorous foes engaged,
while fierce in war divine achilles raged;

spear was so deadly that the trojans dared not show themselves

now issuing fearless they possess the plain,

outside the dardanian gates, but now they sally far from the city

now win the shores, and scarce the seas remain.

and fight even at your ships.

”

”

her speech new fury to their hearts convey’d;

with these words she put heart and soul into them all, while

while near tydides stood the athenian maid;
the king beside his panting steeds she found,

tydeus was a

whose little body lodged a mighty mind;
foremost he press’d in glorious toils to share,

little man, but he could fight, and rushed madly into the fray

and scarce refrain’d when i forbade the war.

even when i told him not to do so.

alone, unguarded, once he dared to go,

there braved, and vanquish’d, many a hardy knight;

was ever present with him, he challenged the youth of the

such nerves i gave him, and such force in fight.

cadmeans, and at once beat them in all that he attempted, so
mightily did i help him.

thou too no less hast been my constant care;

i stand by you too to protect you, and i

bid you be instant in fighting the trojans; but either you are

but thee or fear deters, or sloth detains;

tired out, or you are afraid and out of heart, and in that case i

no drop of all thy father warms thy veins.

say that you are no true son of tydeus the son of oeneus.

the smoking steel.
mars bellows with the pain:

mars

loud as the roar encountering armies yield,
when shouting millions shake the thundering field.

roared as loudly as nine or ten thousand men in the thick of a

both armies start, and trembling gaze around;

fight, and the achaeans and trojans were struck with panic, so

and earth and heaven re-bellow to the sound.

terrible was the cry he raised.

as vapours blown by auster’s sultry breath,
pregnant with plagues, and shedding seeds of death,
beneath the rage of burning sirius rise,
choke the parch’d earth, and blacken all the skies;
in such a cloud the god from combat driven,

as a dark cloud in the sky when it comes on to blow after heat,

high o’er the dusky whirlwind scales the heaven.

even so did diomed son of tydeus see mars ascend into the broad
heavens.

wild with his pain, he sought the bright abodes,

with all speed he reached high olympus, home of the

there sullen sat beneath the sire of gods,

gods, and in great pain sat down beside jove the son of saturn.

he showed jove the immortal blood that was flowing from his

“can jove, supine, flagitious facts survey,

wound, and spoke piteously, saying, “father jove, are you not

and brook the furies of this daring day?

angered by such doings?

for mortal men celestial powers engage,
and gods on gods exert eternal rage:

we gods are continually suffering in the

from thee, o father!

most cruel manner at one another’s hands while helping mortals;

all these ills we bear,

and we all owe you a grudge for having begotten that mad

and thy fell daughter with the shield and spear;
thou gavest that fury to the realms of light,

termagant of a daughter, who is always committing outrage of some

pernicious, wild, regardless of the right.

kind.

all heaven beside reveres thy sovereign sway,
thy voice we hear, and thy behests obey:

we other gods must all do as you bid us, but her you

’tis hers to offend, and even offending share
thy breast, thy counsels, thy distinguish’d care:
so boundless she, and thou so partial grown,

neither scold nor punish; you encourage her because the pestilent

well may we deem the wondrous birth thy own.

creature is your daughter.

now frantic diomed, at her command,

the heavenly venus first his fury found,

first he went up to

me next encountering, me he dared to wound;

the cyprian and wounded her in the hand near her wrist, and then

vanquish’d i fled; even i, the god of fight,

he sprang upon me too as though he were a god.

from mortal madness scarce was saved by flight.

had i not run for

else hadst thou seen me sink on yonder plain,

it i must either have lain there for long enough in torments

heap’d round, and heaving under loads of slain!
or pierced with grecian darts, for ages lie,

among the ghastly corpses, or have been eaten alive with spears

condemn’d to pain, though fated not to die.

till i had no more strength left in me.

”

”

him thus upbraiding, with a wrathful look
the lord of thunders view’d, and stern bespoke:

jove looked angrily at him and said, “do not come whining here,

“to me, perfidious!

sir facing-both-ways.

this lamenting strain?
of lawless force shall lawless mars complain?
of all the gods who tread the spangled skies,
thou most unjust, most odious in our eyes!

i hate you worst of all the gods in

inhuman discord is thy dire delight,
the waste of slaughter, and the rage of fight.

olympus, for you are ever fighting and making mischief.

no bounds, no law, thy fiery temper quells,

you have

and all thy mother in thy soul rebels.
in vain our threats, in vain our power we use;

the intolerable and stubborn spirit of your mother juno: it is

she gives the example, and her son pursues.

all i can do to manage her, and it is her doing that you are now

yet long the inflicted pangs thou shall not mourn,

in this plight: still, i cannot let you remain longer in such

sprung since thou art from jove, and heavenly-born.

great pain; you are my own offspring, and it was by me that your
mother conceived you; if, however, you had been the son of any

else, singed with lightning, hadst thou hence been thrown,

other god, you are so destructive that by this time you should

where chain’d on burning rocks the titans groan.

have been lying lower than the titans.

”

thus he who shakes olympus with his nod;

book vi.
argument.

book vi.

the episodes of glaucus and diomed, and of hector and andromache.
the gods having left the field, the grecians prevail.

glaucus and diomed—the story of bellerophon—hector and

helenus, the

andromache.

chief augur of troy, commands hector to return to the city, in order to
appoint a solemn procession of the queen and the trojan matrons to the
temple of minerva, to entreat her to remove diomed from the fight.
the
battle relaxing during the absence of hector, glaucus and diomed have
an interview between the two armies; where, coming to the knowledge, of
the friendship and hospitality passed between their ancestors, they
make exchange of their arms.
hector, having performed the orders of
helenus, prevails upon paris to return to the battle, and, taking a
tender leave of his wife andromache, hastens again to the field.
the scene is first in the field of battle, between the rivers
simois and scamander, and then changes to troy.
now heaven forsakes the fight: the immortals yield

the fight between trojans and achaeans was now left to rage as it

to human force and human skill the field:

would, and the tide of war surged hither and thither over the

dark showers of javelins fly from foes to foes;

plain as they aimed their bronze-shod spears at one another

now here, now there, the tide of combat flows;
while troy’s famed streams, that bound the deathful plain
on either side, run purple to the main.

between the streams of simois and xanthus.

great ajax first to conquest led the way,

first, ajax son of telamon, tower of strength to the achaeans,

broke the thick ranks, and turn’d the doubtful day.

broke a phalanx of the trojans, and came to the assistance of his

the thracian acamas his falchion found,

comrades by killing acamas son of eussorus, the best man among

and hew’d the enormous giant to the ground;

the thracians, being both brave and of great stature.

his thundering arm a deadly stroke impress’d

the spear

where the black horse-hair nodded o’er his crest;

struck the projecting peak of his helmet: its bronze point then

fix’d in his front the brazen weapon lies,

went through his forehead into the brain, and darkness veiled his

and seals in endless shades his swimming eyes.

eyes.

next teuthras’ son distain’d the sands with blood,
axylus, hospitable, rich, and good:

then diomed killed axylus son of teuthranus, a rich man who lived

in fair arisbe’s walls (his native place)[161]
he held his seat!
a friend to human race.

in the strong city of arisbe, and was beloved by all men; for he

fast by the road, his ever-open door
obliged the wealthy, and relieved the poor.

had a house by the roadside, and entertained every one who

to stern tydides now he falls a prey,
no friend to guard him in the dreadful day!
breathless the good man fell, and by his side

passed; howbeit not one of his guests stood before him to save

his faithful servant, old calesius died.
by great euryalus was dresus slain,

his life, and diomed killed both him and his squire calesius, who

and next he laid opheltius on the plain.

was then his charioteer—so the pair passed beneath the earth.

and he stripped the armour from their shoulders.

well hast thou known proud troy’s perfidious land,

fared so well at the hands of the trojans?

let us not spare a

the monarch spoke; the words, with warmth address’d,

words were just.

to rigid justice steel’d his brother’s breast.

old nestor saw, and roused the warrior’s rage;

“thus, heroes!
thus the vigorous combat wage;
no son of mars descend, for servile gains,

danaan warriors, servants of mars, let no man lag that he may

to touch the booty, while a foe remains.

spoil the dead, and bring back much booty to the ships.
let us

behold yon glittering host, your future spoil!

kill as many as we can; the bodies will lie upon the plain, and

first gain the conquest, then reward the toil.

you can despoil them later at your leisure.

”

”

and now had greece eternal fame acquired,

and now the

and frighted troy within her walls, retired,

where hector stood, with great æneas join’d,

trojans and lycians, for you are foremost at all times, alike in

fight and counsel; hold your ground here, and go about among the

here, at our gates, your brave efforts unite,

foes.

when your commands have hearten’d every band,

then, when you have put heart into all our companies, we

ourselves, here fix’d, will make the dangerous stand;
press’d as we are, and sore of former fight,

will stand firm here and fight the danaans however hard they

these straits demand our last remains of might.

press us, for there is nothing else to be done.

meanwhile thou, hector, to the town retire,

meanwhile do you,

and teach our mother what the gods require:

hector, go to the city and tell our mother what is happening.

and twelve young heifers to her altars led:

twelve yearling heifers that have never yet felt the goad, in the

with fury and fills men’s souls with panic.

that mows whole troops, and makes all troy retire;

i hold him mightiest

not thus achilles taught our hosts to dread,

of them all; we did not fear even their great champion achilles,

sprung though he was from more than mortal bed;

son of a goddess though he be, as we do this man: his rage is

not thus resistless ruled the stream of fight,
in rage unbounded, and unmatch’d in might.

beyond all bounds, and there is none can vie with him in

prowess.
”

hector obedient heard: and, with a bound,

hector did as his brother bade him.

leap’d from his trembling chariot to the ground;

he sprang from his chariot,

through all his host inspiring force he flies,

and went about everywhere among the host, brandishing his spears,

and bids the thunder of the battle rise.

urging the men on to fight, and raising the dread cry of battle.

with rage recruited the bold trojans glow,
and turn the tide of conflict on the foe:
fierce in the front he shakes two dazzling spears;
all greece recedes, and ’midst her triumphs fears;

thereon they rallied and again faced the achaeans, who gave

some god, they thought, who ruled the fate of wars,

ground and ceased their murderous onset, for they deemed that

shot down avenging from the vault of stars.

some one of the immortals had come down from starry heaven to

then thus aloud: “ye dauntless dardans, hear!

help the trojans, so strangely had they rallied.

and you whom distant nations send to war!

and hector

be mindful of the strength your fathers bore;

shouted to the trojans, “trojans and allies, be men, my friends,

be still yourselves, and hector asks no more.
one hour demands me in the trojan wall,

and fight with might and main, while i go to ilius and tell the

to bid our altars flame, and victims fall:
nor shall, i trust, the matrons’ holy train,

old men of our council and our wives to pray to the gods and vow

and reverend elders, seek the gods in vain.

hecatombs in their honour.

”

”

this said, with ample strides the hero pass’d;

with this he went his way, and the black rim of hide that went

the shield’s large orb behind his shoulder cast,
his neck o’ershading, to his ankle hung;

round his shield beat against his neck and his ancles.

and as he march’d the brazen buckler rung.

then glaucus son of hippolochus, and the son of tydeus went into

now paused the battle (godlike hector gone),[167]

the open space between the hosts to fight in single combat.

where daring glaucus and great tydeus’ son

when

between both armies met: the chiefs from far
observed each other, and had mark’d for war.

they were close up to one another diomed of the loud war-cry was

near as they drew, tydides thus began:

the first to speak.

“what art thou, boldest of the race of man?

“who, my good sir,” said he, “who are you
among men?

our eyes till now that aspect ne’er beheld,
where fame is reap’d amid the embattled field;
yet far before the troops thou dar’st appear,

i have never seen you in battle until now, but you are

and meet a lance the fiercest heroes fear.

daring beyond all others if you abide my onset.

unhappy they, and born of luckless sires,

woe to those

who tempt our fury when minerva fires!

fathers whose sons face my might.

but if from heaven, celestial, thou descend,

if, however, you are one of the

know with immortals we no more contend.

immortals and have come down from heaven, i will not fight you;

not long lycurgus view’d the golden light,

for even valiant lycurgus, son of dryas, did not live long when

that daring man who mix’d with gods in fight.

he took to fighting with the gods.

bacchus, and bacchus’ votaries, he drove,

he it was that drove the

with brandish’d steel, from nyssa’s sacred grove:

nursing women who were in charge of frenzied bacchus through the

their consecrated spears lay scatter’d round,

land of nysa, and they flung their thyrsi on the ground as

with curling vines and twisted ivy bound;

murderous lycurgus beat them with his oxgoad.

while bacchus headlong sought the briny flood,

bacchus himself
plunged terror-stricken into the sea, and thetis took him to her
bosom to comfort him, for he was scared by the fury with which

and thetis’ arms received the trembling god.

the man reviled him.

nor fail’d the crime the immortals’ wrath to move;
(the immortals bless’d with endless ease above;)
deprived of sight by their avenging doom,

thereon the gods who live at ease were angry

cheerless he breathed, and wander’d in the gloom,
then sunk unpitied to the dire abodes,

with lycurgus and the son of saturn struck him blind, nor did he

a wretch accursed, and hated by the gods!

live much longer after he had become hateful to the immortals.

i brave not heaven: but if the fruits of earth

therefore i will not fight with the blessed gods; but if you are

sustain thy life, and human be thy birth,
bold as thou art, too prodigal of breath,

of them that eat the fruit of the ground, draw near and meet your

approach, and enter the dark gates of death.

doom.

”

”

“what, or from whence i am, or who my sire,

and the son of hippolochus answered, “son of tydeus, why ask me

(replied the chief,) can tydeus’ son inquire?

of my lineage?

like leaves on trees the race of man is found,

men come and go as leaves year by year upon the
trees.

now green in youth, now withering on the ground;

those of autumn the wind sheds upon the ground, but when

another race the following spring supplies;

spring returns the forest buds forth with fresh vines.

they fall successive, and successive rise:

even so is

so generations in their course decay;

it with the generations of mankind, the new spring up as the old

so flourish these, when those are pass’d away.

are passing away.

but if thou still persist to search my birth,

if, then, you would learn my descent, it is one

then hear a tale that fills the spacious earth.

that is well known to many.

“a city stands on argos’ utmost bound,

there is a city in the heart of

(argos the fair, for warlike steeds renown’d,)
æolian sisyphus, with wisdom bless’d,

argos, pasture land of horses, called ephyra, where sisyphus

in ancient time the happy wall possess’d,

lived, who was the craftiest of all mankind.

then call’d ephyre: glaucus was his son;

he was the son of
aeolus, and had a son named glaucus, who was father to

great glaucus, father of bellerophon,

bellerophon, whom heaven endowed with the most surpassing

who o’er the sons of men in beauty shined,

comeliness and beauty.

loved for that valour which preserves mankind.

but proetus devised his ruin, and being

then mighty praetus argos’ sceptre sway’d,

stronger than he, drove him from the land of the argives, over

whose hard commands bellerophon obey’d.
with direful jealousy the monarch raged,
and the brave prince in numerous toils engaged.

which jove had made him ruler.

for him antaea burn’d with lawless flame,

for antea, wife of proetus, lusted

and strove to tempt him from the paths of fame:

after him, and would have had him lie with her in secret; but

in vain she tempted the relentless youth,
endued with wisdom, sacred fear, and truth.

bellerophon was an honourable man and would not, so she told lies

fired at his scorn the queen to praetus fled,

about him to proetus.

and begg’d revenge for her insulted bed:

‘proetus,’ said she, ‘kill bellerophon or

incensed he heard, resolving on his fate;

die, for he would have had converse with me against my will.

but hospitable laws restrain’d his hate:

king was angered, but shrank from killing bellerophon, so he sent

there lycia’s monarch paid him honours due,

lycia, and the gods convoyed him safely.
“when he reached the river xanthus, which is in lycia, the king

nine days he feasted, and nine bulls he slew.

received him with all goodwill, feasted him nine days, and killed

but when the tenth bright morning orient glow’d,

nine heifers in his honour, but when rosy-fingered morning
appeared upon the tenth day, he questioned him and desired to see

the faithful youth his monarch’s mandate show’d:

the letter from his son-in-law proetus.

the fatal tablets, till that instant seal’d,

when he had received the

the deathful secret to the king reveal’d.
first, dire chimaera’s conquest was enjoin’d;

wicked letter he first commanded bellerophon to kill that savage

a mingled monster of no mortal kind!

monster, the chimaera, who was not a human being, but a goddess,

behind, a dragon’s fiery tail was spread;
a goat’s rough body bore a lion’s head;

for she had the head of a lion and the tail of a serpent, while

her pitchy nostrils flaky flames expire;
her gaping throat emits infernal fire.

her body was that of a goat, and she breathed forth flames of

“this pest he slaughter’d, (for he read the skies,

fire; but bellerophon slew her, for he was guided by signs from

and trusted heaven’s informing prodigies,)

heaven.

then met in arms the solymæan crew,[169]
(fiercest of men,) and those the warrior slew;
next the bold amazons’ whole force defied;

he next fought the far-famed solymi, and this, he said,

and conquer’d still, for heaven was on his side.

was the hardest of all his battles.

“nor ended here his toils: his lycian foes,

thirdly, he killed the

at his return, a treacherous ambush rose,

amazons, women who were the peers of men, and as he was returning
thence the king devised yet another plan for his destruction; he

with levell’d spears along the winding shore:

picked the bravest warriors in all lycia, and placed them in

there fell they breathless, and return’d no more.

ambuscade, but not a man ever came back, for bellerophon killed

“at length the monarch, with repentant grief,

offspring of a god, so he kept him in lycia, gave him his

in all the country, fair with vineyards and tilled fields, to

have and to hold.

with two brave sons and one fair daughter bless’d;

“the king’s daughter bore bellerophon three children, isander,

jove, the lord of counsel, lay with

but when at last, distracted in his mind,

laodameia, and she bore him noble sarpedon; but when bellerophon

forsook by heaven, forsaking humankind,

came to be hated by all the gods, he wandered all desolate and

wide o’er the aleian field he chose to stray,

dismayed upon the alean plain, gnawing at his own heart, and

a long, forlorn, uncomfortable way!
[170]

shunning the path of man.

woes heap’d on woes consumed his wasted heart:

mars, insatiate of battle, killed his

his beauteous daughter fell by phoebe’s dart;
his eldest born by raging mars was slain,

son isander while he was fighting the solymi; his daughter was

in combat on the solymaean plain.

killed by diana of the golden reins, for she was angered with

hippolochus survived: from him i came,
the honour’d author of my birth and name;

her; but hippolochus was father to myself, and when he sent me to

by his decree i sought the trojan town;
by his instructions learn to win renown,
to stand the first in worth as in command,

troy he urged me again and again to fight ever among the foremost

to add new honours to my native land,
before my eyes my mighty sires to place,

and outvie my peers, so as not to shame the blood of my fathers

and emulate the glories of our race.

who were the noblest in ephyra and in all lycia.

”

this, then, is
the descent i claim.
”

he spoke, and transport fill’d tydides’ heart;

thus did he speak, and the heart of diomed was glad.

in earth the generous warrior fix’d his dart,

he planted

then friendly, thus the lycian prince address’d:

his spear in the ground, and spoke to him with friendly words.

“welcome, my brave hereditary guest!
thus ever let us meet, with kind embrace,
nor stain the sacred friendship of our race.
know, chief, our grandsires have been guests of old;

“then,” he said, “you are an old friend of my father’s house.

œneus the strong, bellerophon the bold:
our ancient seat his honour’d presence graced,
where twenty days in genial rites he pass’d.

great oeneus once entertained bellerophon for twenty days, and

the parting heroes mutual presents left;

the two exchanged presents.

a golden goblet was thy grandsire’s gift;
œneus a belt of matchless work bestowed,
that rich with tyrian dye refulgent glow’d.

oeneus gave a belt rich with purple,

(this from his pledge i learn’d, which, safely stored

and bellerophon a double cup, which i left at home when i set out

among my treasures, still adorns my board:

for troy.

for tydeus left me young, when thebe’s wall

i do not remember tydeus, for he was taken from us

beheld the sons of greece untimely fall.

while i was yet a child, when the army of the achaeans was cut to

pieces before thebes.

mindful of this, in friendship let us join;

henceforth, however, i must be your host in

if heaven our steps to foreign lands incline,
my guest in argos thou, and i in lycia thine.

middle argos, and you mine in lycia, if i should ever go there;

enough of trojans to this lance shall yield,

let us avoid one another’s spears even during a general

in the full harvest of yon ample field;

engagement; there are many noble trojans and allies whom i can

enough of greeks shall dye thy spear with gore;

kill, if i overtake them and heaven delivers them into my hand;

but thou and diomed be foes no more.

so again with yourself, there are many achaeans whose lives you

now change we arms, and prove to either host

may take if you can; we two, then, will exchange armour, that all

we guard the friendship of the line we boast.

present may know of the old ties that subsist between us.

”

thus having said, the gallant chiefs alight,

their hands they join, their mutual faith they plight;

another’s hands, and plighted friendship.

brave glaucus then each narrow thought resign’d,

but the son of saturn

(jove warm’d his bosom, and enlarged his mind,)
for diomed’s brass arms, of mean device,
for which nine oxen paid, (a vulgar price,)
he gave his own, of gold divinely wrought,[171]

made glaucus take leave of his wits, for he exchanged golden

a hundred beeves the shining purchase bought.
meantime the guardian of the trojan state,

and now to priam’s stately courts he came,

the rich pavilions of his fifty sons,

offering to jove and to the other immortals, and may then drink

and be refreshed.

and draw new spirits from the generous bowl;

wine gives a man fresh strength when he is

spent as thou art with long laborious fight,
the brave defender of thy country’s right.

wearied, as you now are with fighting on behalf of your kinsmen.

”

”

“far hence be bacchus’ gifts; (the chief rejoin’d;)
inflaming wine, pernicious to mankind,

and hector answered, “honoured mother, bring no wine, lest you

unnerves the limbs, and dulls the noble mind.

unman me and i forget my strength.

let chiefs abstain, and spare the sacred juice

i dare not make a

to sprinkle to the gods, its better use.
by me that holy office were profaned;
ill fits it me, with human gore distain’d,

while they were thus praying to the daughter of great jove,

hector to paris’ lofty dome repairs.
[175]

hector went to the fair house of alexandrus, which he had built

himself the mansion raised, from every part

for him by the foremost builders in the land.

assembling architects of matchless art.

they had built him

near priam’s court and hector’s palace stands

his house, storehouse, and courtyard near those of priam and

the pompous structure, and the town commands.

hector on the acropolis.

a spear the hero bore of wondrous strength,
of full ten cubits was the lance’s length,

here hector entered, with a spear eleven

the steely point with golden ringlets join’d,
before him brandish’d, at each motion shined

cubits long in his hand; the bronze point gleamed in front of

thus entering, in the glittering rooms he found

him, and was fastened to the shaft of the spear by a ring of

his brother-chief, whose useless arms lay round,

gold.

his eyes delighting with their splendid show,

he found alexandrus within the house, busied about his

brightening the shield, and polishing the bow.

armour, his shield and cuirass, and handling his curved bow;

beside him helen with her virgins stands,

there, too, sat argive helen with her women, setting them their

guides their rich labours, and instructs their hands.
him thus inactive, with an ardent look

several tasks; and as hector saw him he rebuked him with words of

the prince beheld, and high-resenting spoke.

scorn.

“thy hate to troy, is this the time to show?
(o wretch ill-fated, and thy country’s foe!
)

“sir,” said he, “you do ill to nurse this rancour; the

paris and greece against us both conspire,
thy close resentment, and their vengeful ire.
for thee great ilion’s guardian heroes fall,
till heaps of dead alone defend her wall,
for thee the soldier bleeds, the matron mourns,
and wasteful war in all its fury burns.
ungrateful man!
deserves not this thy care,

people perish fighting round this our town; you would yourself

our troops to hearten, and our toils to share?

chide one whom you saw shirking his part in the combat.

rise, or behold the conquering flames ascend,

up then,

and all the phrygian glories at an end.

or ere long the city will be in a blaze.

”

”

“brother, ’tis just, (replied the beauteous youth,)
thy free remonstrance proves thy worth and truth:

and alexandrus answered, “hector, your rebuke is just; listen

yet charge my absence less, o generous chief!

therefore, and believe me when i tell you that i am not here so

on hate to troy, than conscious shame and grief:
here, hid from human eyes, thy brother sate,

much through rancour or ill-will towards the trojans, as from a

and mourn’d, in secret, his and ilion’s fate.

desire to indulge my grief.

’tis now enough; now glory spreads her charms,
and beauteous helen calls her chief to arms.

my wife was even now gently urging me

conquest to-day my happier sword may bless,

to battle, and i hold it better that i should go, for victory is

’tis man’s to fight, but heaven’s to give success.

ever fickle.

but while i arm, contain thy ardent mind;

wait, then, while i put on my armour, or go first

or go, and paris shall not lag behind.

and i will follow.
i shall be sure to overtake you.

”
[illustration: ] hector chiding paris

”

he said, nor answer’d priam’s warlike son;
when helen thus with lowly grace begun:

hector made no answer, but helen tried to soothe him.

“oh, generous brother!
(if the guilty dame
that caused these woes deserve a sister’s name!
)

“brother,”

would heaven, ere all these dreadful deeds were done,

said she, “to my abhorred and sinful self, would that a whirlwind

the day that show’d me to the golden sun
had seen my death!

had caught me up on the day my mother brought me forth, and had

why did not whirlwinds bear
the fatal infant to the fowls of air?

borne me to some mountain or to the waves of the roaring sea that

why sunk i not beneath the whelming tide,

should have swept me away ere this mischief had come about.

and midst the roarings of the waters died?

but,

heaven fill’d up all my ills, and i accursed
bore all, and paris of those ills the worst.

since the gods have devised these evils, would, at any rate, that

helen at least a braver spouse might claim,

i had been wife to a better man—to one who could smart under

warm’d with some virtue, some regard of fame!

dishonour and men’s evil speeches.

now tired with toils, thy fainting limbs recline,

this fellow was never yet to

with toils, sustain’d for paris’ sake and mine

be depended upon, nor never will be, and he will surely reap what

the gods have link’d our miserable doom,

he has sown.

our present woe, and infamy to come:

still, brother, come in and rest upon this seat, for

wide shall it spread, and last through ages long,

it is you who bear the brunt of that toil that has been caused by

example sad!

my hateful self and by the sin of alexandrus—both of whom jove

and theme of future song.

has doomed to be a theme of song among those that shall be born

hereafter.

the chief replied: “this time forbids to rest;
the trojan bands, by hostile fury press’d,

and hector answered, “bid me not be seated, helen, for all the

demand their hector, and his arm require;

goodwill you bear me.

the combat urges, and my soul’s on fire.

i cannot stay.

urge thou thy knight to march where glory calls,

i am in haste to help the

and timely join me, ere i leave the walls.

trojans, who miss me greatly when i am not among them; but urge

ere yet i mingle in the direful fray,

your husband, and of his own self also let him make haste to

my wife, my infant, claim a moment’s stay;

overtake me before i am out of the city.

this day (perhaps the last that sees me here)

i must go home to see my

demands a parting word, a tender tear:

this day, some god who hates our trojan land

may vanquish hector by a grecian hand.

me to fall by the hands of the achaeans.

”

”

he said, and pass’d with sad presaging heart
to seek his spouse, his soul’s far dearer part;
at home he sought her, but he sought in vain;
she, with one maid of all her menial train,
had hence retired; and with her second joy,

then hector left her, and forthwith was at his own house.

the young astyanax, the hope of troy,

he did

pensive she stood on ilion’s towery height,

of ilius, for she had heard the trojans were being hard pressed,

the nurse attended with her infant boy,

hector this heard, return’d without delay;

astyanax, for his father stood alone as chief guardian of ilius.

and the big tear stood trembling in her eye.

so shall my days in one sad tenor run,
and end with sorrows as they first begun.

comfort me when you are gone, save only sorrow.

no parent now remains my griefs to share,

i have neither

no father’s aid, no mother’s tender care.

father nor mother now.

the fierce achilles wrapt our walls in fire,

best scaled, and the wall is weakest.

there agamemnon points his dreadful host,

the chief replied: “that post shall be my care,

and hector answered, “wife, i too have thought upon all this, but

how would the sons of troy, in arms renown’d,
and troy’s proud dames, whose garments sweep the ground
attaint the lustre of my former name,

with what face should i look upon the trojans, men or women, if i

should hector basely quit the field of fame?
my early youth was bred to martial pains,

shirked battle like a coward?

my soul impels me to the embattled plains!

i cannot do so: i know nothing save

let me be foremost to defend the throne,

to fight bravely in the forefront of the trojan host and win

and guard my father’s glories, and my own.
“yet come it will, the day decreed by fates!
(how my heart trembles while my tongue relates!

renown alike for my father and myself.

)

well do i know that the

the day when thou, imperial troy!
must bend,
and see thy warriors fall, thy glories end.

day will surely come when mighty ilius shall be destroyed with

and yet no dire presage so wounds my mind,
my mother’s death, the ruin of my kind,
not priam’s hoary hairs defiled with gore,

priam and priam’s people, but i grieve for none of these—not even

not all my brothers gasping on the shore;

for hecuba, nor king priam, nor for my brothers many and brave
who may fall in the dust before their foes—for none of these do i

as thine, andromache!

grieve as for yourself when the day shall come on which some one

thy griefs i dread:

of the achaeans shall rob you for ever of your freedom, and bear

i see thee trembling, weeping, captive led!

you weeping away.

in argive looms our battles to design,

it may be that you will have to ply the loom in

your cry as they carry you into bondage.

“andromache!
my soul’s far better part,

bitterly to heart.

no hostile hand can antedate my doom,
till fate condemns me to the silent tomb.

no one can hurry me down to hades before my

fix’d is the term to all the race of earth;

time, but if a man’s hour is come, be he brave or be he coward,

and such the hard condition of our birth:
no force can then resist, no flight can save,

there is no escape for him when he has once been born.

all sink alike, the fearful and the brave.

go, then,

no more—but hasten to thy tasks at home,

within the house, and busy yourself with your daily duties, your

there guide the spindle, and direct the loom:
me glory summons to the martial scene,
the field of combat is the sphere for men.

loom, your distaff, and the ordering of your servants; for war is

where heroes war, the foremost place i claim,

man’s matter, and mine above all others of them that have been

the first in danger as the first in fame.

born in ilius.

”

”

thus having said, the glorious chief resumes
his towery helmet, black with shading plumes.
his princess parts with a prophetic sigh,

he took his plumed helmet from the ground, and his wife went back

unwilling parts, and oft reverts her eye

again to her house, weeping bitterly and often looking back

that stream’d at every look; then, moving slow,

towards him.

sought her own palace, and indulged her woe.

when she reached her home she found her maidens

there, while her tears deplored the godlike man,
through all her train the soft infection ran;
the pious maids their mingled sorrows shed,

within, and bade them all join in her lament; so they mourned

and mourn the living hector, as the dead.

hector in his own house though he was yet alive, for they deemed

but now, no longer deaf to honour’s call,

that they should never see him return safe from battle, and from

forth issues paris from the palace wall.

the furious hands of the achaeans.
paris did not remain long in his house.

in brazen arms that cast a gleamy ray,

swift through the town the warrior bends his way.

armour overlaid with bronze, and hasted through the city as fast

the wanton courser thus with reins unbound[176]

as his feet could take him.

breaks from his stall, and beats the trembling ground;

as a horse, stabled and fed, breaks

pamper’d and proud, he seeks the wonted tides,
and laves, in height of blood his shining sides;

loose and gallops gloriously over the plain to the place where he

his head now freed, he tosses to the skies;

is wont to bathe in the fair-flowing river—he holds his head

his mane dishevell’d o’er his shoulders flies;
he snuffs the females in the distant plain,

and springs, exulting, to his fields again.

strength and flies like the wind to the haunts and feeding ground

of the mares—even so went forth paris from high pergamus,

the son of priam, glorying in his might,

sped swiftly on his way.

and now, the warriors passing on the way,

“sir,” said he, “i fear that i have kept you waiting when

“o chief!

”

in blood, and now in arms, allied!

“my good brother,” answered hector, “you fight bravely, and no

thy power in war with justice none contest;

man with any justice can make light of your doings in battle.
but

known is thy courage, and thy strength confess’d.

you are careless and wilfully remiss.

what pity sloth should seize a soul so brave,

it grieves me to the heart

or godlike paris live a woman’s slave!
my heart weeps blood at what the trojans say,
and hopes thy deeds shall wipe the stain away.
haste then, in all their glorious labours share,

for much they suffer, for thy sake, in war.

book vii.
argument

book vii.

the single combat of hector and ajax.
the battle renewing with double ardour upon the return of hector,
minerva is under apprehensions for the greeks.
apollo, seeing her
descend from olympus, joins her near the scæan gate.
they agree to put
off the general engagement for that day, and incite hector to challenge
the greeks to a single combat.
nine of the princes accepting the
challenge, the lot is cast and falls upon ajax.
these heroes, after
several attacks, are parted by the night.
the trojans calling a
council, antenor purposes the delivery of helen to the greeks, to which
paris will not consent, but offers to restore them her riches.
priam
sends a herald to make this offer, and to demand a truce for burning
the dead, the last of which only is agreed to by agamemnon.
when the
funerals are performed, the greeks, pursuant to the advice of nestor,
erect a fortification to protect their fleet and camp, flanked with
towers, and defended by a ditch and palisades.
neptune testifies his
jealousy at this work, but is pacified by a promise from jupiter.
both
armies pass the night in feasting but jupiter disheartens the trojans
with thunder, and other signs of his wrath.
the three and twentieth day ends with the duel of hector and ajax,

hector and ajax fight—hector is getting worsted when night comes

the next day the truce is agreed; another is taken up in the
funeral rites of the slain and one more in building the

on and parts them—they exchange presents—the burial of the dead,

fortification before the ships.
so that somewhat about three days

and the building of a wall round their ships by the achaeans—the

is employed in this book.
the scene lies wholly in the field.

achaeans buy their wine of agamemnon and menelaus.

so spoke the guardian of the trojan state,
then rush’d impetuous through the scæan gate.

with these words hector passed through the gates, and his brother

him paris follow’d to the dire alarms;
both breathing slaughter, both resolved in arms.

alexandrus with him, both eager for the fray.

as when to sailors labouring through the main,

as when heaven

that long have heaved the weary oar in vain,
jove bids at length the expected gales arise;

sends a breeze to sailors who have long looked for one in vain,

the gales blow grateful, and the vessel flies.

and have laboured at their oars till they are faint with toil,

so welcome these to troy’s desiring train,
the bands are cheer’d, the war awakes again.

even so welcome was the sight of these two heroes to the trojans.

bold paris first the work of death begun

thereon alexandrus killed menesthius the son of areithous; he

on great menestheus, areithous’ son,

lived in arne, and was son of areithous the mace-man, and of

sprung from the fair philomeda’s embrace,

phylomedusa.

the pleasing arnè was his native place.
then sunk eioneus to the shades below,

hector threw a spear at eioneus and struck him dead

beneath his steely casque[177] he felt the blow
full on his neck, from hector’s weighty hand;

with a wound in the neck under the bronze rim of his helmet.

and roll’d, with limbs relax’d, along the land.

glaucus, moreover, son of hippolochus, captain of the lycians, in

by glaucus’ spear the bold iphinous bleeds,

hard hand-to-hand fight smote iphinous son of dexius on the

fix’d in the shoulder as he mounts his steeds;

shoulder, as he was springing on to his chariot behind his fleet

headlong he tumbles: his slack nerves unbound,

mares; so he fell to earth from the car, and there was no life

drop the cold useless members on the ground.

left in him.

when now minerva saw her argives slain,

from vast olympus to the gleaming plain

nor shot less swift from ilion’s towery height.

her; for he wanted the trojans to be victorious.
the pair met by

“what cause, o daughter of almighty jove!

the oak tree, and king apollo son of jove was first to speak.
“what would you have,” said he, “daughter of great jove, that

thus wings thy progress from the realms above?

your proud spirit has sent you hither from olympus?

once more impetuous dost thou bend thy way,

have you no
pity upon the trojans, and would you incline the scales of

to give to greece the long divided day?

victory in favour of the danaans?

too much has troy already felt thy hate,

let me persuade you—for it will

now breathe thy rage, and hush the stern debate;
this day, the business of the field suspend;

be better thus—stay the combat for to-day, but let them renew the

war soon shall kindle, and great ilion bend;
since vengeful goddesses confederate join

fight hereafter till they compass the doom of ilius, since you

to raze her walls, though built by hands divine.

goddesses have made up your minds to destroy the city.

”

”

to whom the progeny of jove replies:

and minerva answered, “so be it, far-darter; it was in this mind

“i left, for this, the council of the skies:

that i came down from olympus to the trojans and achaeans.

but who shall bid conflicting hosts forbear,

tell

what art shall calm the furious sons of war?

me, then, how do you propose to end this present fighting?

”

”

to her the god: “great hector’s soul incite

till greece, provoked, from all her numbers show

a warrior worthy to be hector’s foe.

achaeans will be shamed into finding a man who will fight him.

”

”

at this agreed, the heavenly powers withdrew;
sage helenus their secret counsels knew;

minerva assented, and helenus son of priam divined the counsel of

hector, inspired, he sought: to him address’d,
thus told the dictates of his sacred breast:

the gods; he therefore went up to hector and said, “hector son of

“o son of priam!

priam, peer of gods in counsel, i am your brother, let me then

persuade you.

go forth persuasive, and a while engage

the warring nations to suspend their rage;

their seats, and challenge the best man among the achaeans to

to mortal combat on the listed plain.

i have heard the voice of the

for not this day shall end thy glorious date;
the gods have spoke it, and their voice is fate.

ever-living gods, and the hour of your doom is not yet come.

”

”

he said: the warrior heard the word with joy;

trojans, grasping his spear by the middle to hold them back, and

they all sat down.

the squadrons part; the expecting trojans stand;
great agamemnon bids the greeks forbear:

agamemnon also bade the achaeans be seated.

they breathe, and hush the tumult of the war.
the athenian maid,[178] and glorious god of day,
with silent joy the settling hosts survey:

but minerva and apollo, in the likeness of vultures, perched on

in form of vultures, on the beech’s height

father jove’s high oak tree, proud of their men; and the ranks

they sit conceal’d, and wait the future fight.
the thronging troops obscure the dusky fields,

sat close ranged together, bristling with shield and helmet and

horrid with bristling spears, and gleaming shields.

spear.

as when a general darkness veils the main,
(soft zephyr curling the wide wat’ry plain,)
the waves scarce heave, the face of ocean sleeps,

as when the rising west wind furs the face of the sea and

and a still horror saddens all the deeps;
thus in thick orders settling wide around,

the waters grow dark beneath it, so sat the companies of trojans

at length composed they sit, and shade the ground.

and achaeans upon the plain.

great hector first amidst both armies broke
the solemn silence, and their powers bespoke:

and hector spoke thus:—

“hear, all ye trojan, all ye grecian bands,
what my soul prompts, and what some god commands.

“hear me, trojans and achaeans, that i may speak even as i am

great jove, averse our warfare to compose,

minded; jove on his high throne has brought our oaths and

o’erwhelms the nations with new toils and woes;
war with a fiercer tide once more returns,

covenants to nothing, and foreshadows ill for both of us, till

till ilion falls, or till yon navy burns.
you then, o princes of the greeks!

you either take the towers of troy, or are yourselves vanquished

appear;

at your ships.

’tis hector speaks, and calls the gods to hear:
from all your troops select the boldest knight,

the princes of the achaeans are here present in

and him, the boldest, hector dares to fight.

the midst of you; let him, then, that will fight me stand forward
as your champion against hector.

here if i fall, by chance of battle slain,

thus i say, and may jove be
witness between us.
if your champion slay me, let him strip me of

be his my spoil, and his these arms remain;
but let my body, to my friends return’d,

my armour and take it to your ships, but let him send my body

by trojan hands and trojan flames be burn’d.

home that the trojans and their wives may give me my dues of fire

and if apollo, in whose aid i trust,

when i am dead.
in like manner, if apollo vouchsafe me glory and

shall stretch your daring champion in the dust;

i slay your champion, i will strip him of his armour and take it

if mine the glory to despoil the foe;

to the city of ilius, where i will hang it in the temple of

on phœbus’ temple i’ll his arms bestow:

apollo, but i will give up his body, that the achaeans may bury

the breathless carcase to your navy sent,

him at their ships, and then build him a mound by the wide waters

greece on the shore shall raise a monument;

of the hellespont.

which when some future mariner surveys,

then will one say hereafter as he sails his

wash’d by broad hellespont’s resounding seas,
thus shall he say, ‘a valiant greek lies there,

ship over the sea, ‘this is the monument of one who died long

by hector slain, the mighty man of war,’

since a champion who was slain by mighty hector.

the stone shall tell your vanquish’d hero’s name

’ thus will one

and distant ages learn the victor’s fame.

say, and my fame shall not be lost.

”

”

this fierce defiance greece astonish’d heard,

thus did he speak, but they all held their peace, ashamed to

blush’d to refuse, and to accept it fear’d.

decline the challenge, yet fearing to accept it, till at last

stern menelaus first the silence broke,

menelaus rose and rebuked them, for he was angry.

and, inly groaning, thus opprobrious spoke:

“alas,” he

“women of greece!
o scandal of your race,

cried, “vain braggarts, women forsooth not men, double-dyed

whose coward souls your manly form disgrace,
how great the shame, when every age shall know
that not a grecian met this noble foe!

indeed will be the stain upon us if no man of the danaans will

go then!

now face hector.

resolve to earth, from whence ye grew,

may you be turned every man of you into earth

a heartless, spiritless, inglorious crew!

and water as you sit spiritless and inglorious in your places.

be what ye seem, unanimated clay,

i

myself will dare the danger of the day;
’tis man’s bold task the generous strife to try,

will myself go out against this man, but the upshot of the fight

but in the hands of god is victory.

will be from on high in the hands of the immortal gods.

”

”

these words scarce spoke, with generous ardour press’d,
his manly limbs in azure arms he dress’d.
that day, atrides!

to this folly.

and tempt a fate which prudence bids thee shun?

be patient in spite of passion, do not think of

great hector’s arm is mightier far than thine:

even fierce achilles learn’d its force to fear,

the mightiest warrior of the achaian name,

though bold and burning with desire of fame,
content the doubtful honour might forego,

of battle though he be, i ween his knees will bend gladly under

so great the danger, and so brave the foe.

him if he comes out alive from the hurly-burly of this fight.

”

he said, and turn’d his brother’s vengeful mind;

with these words of reasonable counsel he persuaded his brother,

he stoop’d to reason, and his rage resign’d,
no longer bent to rush on certain harms;
his joyful friends unbrace his azure arms.
he from whose lips divine persuasion flows,

by the huge, knotted, iron mace he bore;

mace-man,’ because he fought neither with bow nor spear, but
broke the battalions of the foe with his iron mace.

no lance he shook, nor bent the twanging bow,

lycurgus

but broke, with this, the battle of the foe.

earth on his back.

among us.

“warriors!

be mine the conquest of this chief of troy.

for i shall vanquish hector.

now while my brightest arms my limbs invest,

i will put on my armour; meanwhile,

to saturn’s son be all your vows address’d:
but pray in secret, lest the foes should hear,

pray to king jove in silence among yourselves that the trojans

and deem your prayers the mean effect of fear.

may not hear you—or aloud if you will, for we fear no man.

said i in secret?
no, your vows declare

none

in such a voice as fills the earth and air,
lives there a chief whom ajax ought to dread?

shall overcome me, neither by force nor cunning, for i was born

ajax, in all the toils of battle bred!
from warlike salamis i drew my birth,
and, born to combats, fear no force on earth.

and bred in salamis, and can hold my own in all things.

”
he said.

”

the troops with elevated eyes,

with this they fell praying to king jove the son of saturn, and

implore the god whose thunder rends the skies:

thus would one of them say as he looked into the vault of heaven,

“o father of mankind, superior lord!
on lofty ida’s holy hill adored:
who in the highest heaven hast fix’d thy throne,
supreme of gods!

“father jove that rulest from ida, most glorious in power,

unbounded and alone:

vouchsafe victory to ajax, and let him win great glory: but if

grant thou, that telamon may bear away
the praise and conquest of this doubtful day;
or, if illustrious hector be thy care,

you wish well to hector also and would protect him, grant to each

that both may claim it, and that both may share.

of them equal fame and prowess.

”

”

now ajax braced his dazzling armour on;

sheathed in bright steel the giant-warrior shone:

bronze.

he moves to combat with majestic pace;
so stalks in arms the grisly god of thrace,[182]

when he was in full array he sprang forward as monstrous

when jove to punish faithless men prepares,
and gives whole nations to the waste of wars,

mars when he takes part among men whom jove has set fighting with

thus march’d the chief, tremendous as a god;

one another—even so did huge ajax, bulwark of the achaeans,

grimly he smiled; earth trembled as he strode:[183]

spring forward with a grim smile on his face as he brandished his

his massy javelin quivering in his hand,

long spear and strode onward.

he stood, the bulwark of the grecian band.

the argives were elated as they

through every argive heart new transport ran;
all troy stood trembling at the mighty man:

beheld him, but the trojans trembled in every limb, and the heart

even hector paused; and with new doubt oppress’d,

even of hector beat quickly, but he could not now retreat and

felt his great heart suspended in his breast:
’twas vain to seek retreat, and vain to fear;

withdraw into the ranks behind him, for he had been the

himself had challenged, and the foe drew near.

challenger.

stern telamon behind his ample shield,

ajax came up bearing his shield in front of him like

as from a brazen tower, o’erlook’d the field.
huge was its orb, with seven thick folds o’ercast,
of tough bull-hides; of solid brass the last,

a wall—a shield of bronze with seven folds of ox-hide—the work of

(the work of tychius, who in hylè dwell’d

and in all arts of armoury excell’d,)

leather.

this ajax bore before his manly breast,

he had made it with the hides of seven full-fed bulls,

and, threatening, thus his adverse chief address’d:

and over these he had set an eighth layer of bronze.

“hector!

holding this

shield before him, ajax son of telamon came close up to hector,

what strength thou hast, and what the grecian foe.

and menaced him saying, “hector, you shall now learn, man to man,

achilles shuns the fight; yet some there are,

what kind of champions the danaans have among them even besides

not void of soul, and not unskill’d in war:

lion-hearted achilles cleaver of the ranks of men.

let him, unactive on the sea-beat shore,

he now abides

indulge his wrath, and aid our arms no more;
whole troops of heroes greece has yet to boast,
and sends thee one, a sample of her host,

at the ships in anger with agamemnon shepherd of his people, but

such as i am, i come to prove thy might;

there are many of us who are well able to face you; therefore

no more—be sudden, and begin the fight.

begin the fight.

”

”

“o son of telamon, thy country’s pride!
(to ajax thus the trojan prince replied)

me, as a boy, or woman, wouldst thou fright,

host, treat me not as though i were some puny boy or woman that

new to the field, and trembling at the fight?

cannot fight.

thou meet’st a chief deserving of thy arms,

i have been long used to the blood and butcheries

to combat born, and bred amidst alarms:

of battle.

i know to shift my ground, remount the car,

i am quick to turn my leathern shield either to right

turn, charge, and answer every call of war;
to right, to left, the dexterous lance i wield,

or left, for this i deem the main thing in battle.

and bear thick battle on my sounding shield/

i can charge

but open be our fight, and bold each blow;

among the chariots and horsemen, and in hand to hand fighting can

i steal no conquest from a noble foe.

delight the heart of mars; howbeit i would not take such a man as
you are off his guard—but i will smite you openly if i can.

”

”

he said, and rising, high above the field

he poised his spear as he spoke, and hurled it from him.

“forbear, my sons!
your further force to prove,
both dear to men, and both beloved of jove.
to either host your matchless worth is known,
each sounds your praise, and war is all your own.

“my sons, fight no longer, you are both of you valiant, and both

but now the night extends her awful shade;

are dear to jove; we know this; but night is now falling, and the

the goddess parts you; be the night obey’d.

behests of night may not be well gainsaid.

”[184]

”

to whom great ajax his high soul express’d:
“o sage!
to hector be these words address’d.

ajax son of telamon answered, “idaeus, bid hector say so, for it

let him demand the sanction of the night;

was he that challenged our princes.

“o first of greeks!

(his noble foe rejoin’d)
whom heaven adorns, superior to thy kind,

then hector said, “ajax, heaven has vouchsafed you stature and

with strength of body, and with worth of mind!

strength, and judgement; and in wielding the spear you excel all

now martial law commands us to forbear;

others of the achaeans.

hereafter we shall meet in glorious war,
some future day shall lengthen out the strife,

let us for this day cease fighting;

and let the gods decide of death or life!

hereafter we will fight anew till heaven decide between us, and

since, then, the night extends her gloomy shade,

give victory to one or to the other; night is now falling, and

and heaven enjoins it, be the night obey’d.

the behests of night may not be well gainsaid.

return, brave ajax, to thy grecian friends,

gladden, then, the

and joy the nations whom thy arm defends;

hearts of the achaeans at your ships, and more especially those
of your own followers and clansmen, while i, in the great city of

king priam, bring comfort to the trojans and their women, who vie

who wearies heaven with vows for hector’s life.

with one another in their prayers on my behalf.

but let us, on this memorable day,

exchange some gift: that greece and troy may say,

exchange presents that it may be said among the achaeans and

‘not hate, but glory, made these chiefs contend;

trojans, ‘they fought with might and main, but were reconciled

and each brave foe was in his soul a friend.

and parted in friendship.
