the victim falls; they strip the smoking hide,

they flayed the carcass, made it ready, and

the beast they quarter, and the joints divide;

divided it into joints; these they cut carefully up into smaller
pieces, putting them on the spits, roasting them sufficiently,

then spread the tables, the repast prepare,

and then drawing them off.

each takes his seat, and each receives his share.

when they had done all this and had
prepared the feast, they ate it, and every man had his full and

the king himself (an honorary sign)

equal share, so that all were satisfied, and king agamemnon gave

before great ajax placed the mighty chine.

ajax some slices cut lengthways down the loin, as a mark of

[185]

special honour.

when now the rage of hunger was removed,

as soon as they had had enough to eat and drink,

nestor, in each persuasive art approved,
the sage whose counsels long had sway’d the rest,

old nestor whose counsel was ever truest began to speak; with all

in words like these his prudent thought express’d:

sincerity and goodwill, therefore, he addressed them thus:—

“how dear, o kings!

“son of atreus, and other chieftains, inasmuch as many of the

this fatal day has cost,
what greeks are perish’d!
what a people lost!
what tides of blood have drench’d scamander’s shore!

achaeans are now dead, whose blood mars has shed by the banks of

what crowds of heroes sunk to rise no more!

the scamander, and their souls have gone down to the house of

then hear me, chief!
nor let the morrow’s light

hades, it will be well when morning comes that we should cease

awake thy squadrons to new toils of fight:
some space at least permit the war to breathe,

fighting; we will then wheel our dead together with oxen and

while we to flames our slaughter’d friends bequeath,
from the red field their scatter’d bodies bear,
and nigh the fleet a funeral structure rear;

mules and burn them not far from the ships, that when we sail

so decent urns their snowy bones may keep,

hence we may take the bones of our comrades home to their

and pious children o’er their ashes weep.

children.

here, where on one promiscuous pile they blazed,

hard by the funeral pyre we will build a barrow that

high o’er them all a general tomb be raised;

shall be raised from the plain for all in common; near this let

next, to secure our camp and naval powers,
raise an embattled wall, with lofty towers;

us set about building a high wall, to shelter ourselves and our

from space to space be ample gates around,

ships, and let it have well-made gates that there may be a way

”

’twas thus the sage his wholesome counsel moved;
the sceptred kings of greece his words approved.

thus he spoke, and the princes shouted in applause.

meanwhile, convened at priam’s palace-gate,

meanwhile

the trojan peers in nightly council sate;

the trojans held a council, angry and full of discord, on the

a senate void of order, as of choice:

acropolis by the gates of king priam’s palace; and wise antenor

their hearts were fearful, and confused their voice.

spoke.

antenor, rising, thus demands their ear:
“ye trojans, dardans, and auxiliars, hear!

“hear me,” he said, “trojans, dardanians, and allies, that

’tis heaven the counsel of my breast inspires,

i may speak even as i am minded.

and i but move what every god requires:

let us give up argive helen and

let sparta’s treasures be this hour restored,
and argive helen own her ancient lord.

her wealth to the sons of atreus, for we are now fighting in

the ties of faith, the sworn alliance, broke,
our impious battles the just gods provoke.

violation of our solemn covenants, and shall not prosper till we

as this advice ye practise, or reject,
so hope success, or dread the dire effect.

have done as i say.

”

”

the senior spoke and sate.

he then sat down and alexandrus husband of lovely helen rose to

to whom replied

speak.

the graceful husband of the spartan bride:
“cold counsels, trojan, may become thy years
but sound ungrateful in a warrior’s ears:
old man, if void of fallacy or art,
thy words express the purpose of thy heart,

“antenor,” said he, “your words are not to my liking; you

thou, in thy time, more sound advice hast given;

can find a better saying than this if you will; if, however, you

but wisdom has its date, assign’d by heaven.

have spoken in good earnest, then indeed has heaven robbed you of
your reason.

then hear me, princes of the trojan name!

i will speak plainly, and hereby notify to the

their treasures i’ll restore, but not the dame;

trojans that i will not give up the woman; but the wealth that i

my treasures too, for peace, i will resign;

brought home with her from argos i will restore, and will add yet

but be this bright possession ever mine.

further of my own.

and whose the conquest, mighty jove decide!

between us and give victory to one or to the other.

so toil’d the greeks: meanwhile the gods above,

thus did the achaeans toil, and the gods, seated by the side of

in shining circle round their father jove,
amazed beheld the wondrous works of man:

jove the lord of lightning, marvelled at their great work; but

then he, whose trident shakes the earth, began:

neptune, lord of the earthquake, spoke, saying, “father jove,

“what mortals henceforth shall our power adore,

what mortal in the whole world will again take the gods into his

our fanes frequent, our oracles implore,

counsel?

if the proud grecians thus successful boast

see you not how the achaeans have built a wall about

their rising bulwarks on the sea-beat coast?

their ships and driven a trench all round it, without offering
hecatombs to the gods?

see the long walls extending to the main,

the fame of this wall will reach as far as

no god consulted, and no victim slain!
their fame shall fill the world’s remotest ends,

dawn itself, and men will no longer think anything of the one

wide as the morn her golden beam extends;
while old laomedon’s divine abodes,
those radiant structures raised by labouring gods,

which phoebus apollo and myself built with so much labour for

shall, razed and lost, in long oblivion sleep.

laomedon.

”

”

thus spoke the hoary monarch of the deep.
the almighty thunderer with a frown replies,

jove was displeased and answered, “what, o shaker of the earth,

that clouds the world, and blackens half the skies:

are you talking about?

“strong god of ocean!
thou, whose rage can make
the solid earth’s eternal basis shake!
what cause of fear from mortal works could move[187]
the meanest subject of our realms above?

a god less powerful than yourself might be

where’er the sun’s refulgent rays are cast,
thy power is honour’d, and thy fame shall last.
but yon proud work no future age shall view,

alarmed at what they are doing, but your fame reaches as far as

no trace remain where once the glory grew.

dawn itself.

the sapp’d foundations by thy force shall fall,

surely when the achaeans have gone home with their

and, whelm’d beneath the waves, drop the huge wall:

ships, you can shatter their wall and fling it into the sea; you

vast drifts of sand shall change the former shore:

can cover the beach with sand again, and the great wall of the

the ruin vanish’d, and the name no more.

achaeans will then be utterly effaced.

”

”

thus they in heaven: while, o’er the grecian train,
the rolling sun descending to the main

and well the plenteous freight supplied the host:

from this supply the achaeans bought their wine, some with

each, in exchange, proportion’d treasures gave;[188]

bronze, some with iron, some with hides, some with whole heifers,

some, brass or iron; some, an ox, or slave.

and some again with captives.

mighty son of saturn.

book viii.
argument.

book viii.

the second battle, and the distress of the greeks.
jupiter assembles a council of the deities, and threatens them with the

jove forbids the gods to interfere further—there is an even fight

pains of tartarus if they assist either side: minerva only obtains of

till midday, but then jove inclines the scales of victory in

him that she may direct the greeks by her counsels.
the armies join
battle: jupiter on mount ida weighs in his balances the fates of both,
and affrights the greeks with his thunders and lightnings.
nestor alone
continues in the field in great danger: diomed relieves him; whose
exploits, and those of hector, are excellently described.
juno
endeavours to animate neptune to the assistance of the greeks, but in
vain.
the acts of teucer, who is at length wounded by hector, and
carried off.

favour of the trojans, who eventually chase the achaeans within

juno and minerva prepare to aid the grecians, but are

their wall—juno and minerva set out to help the trojans: jove

restrained by iris, sent from jupiter.

sends iris to turn them back, but later on he promises juno that

the night puts an end to the
battle.
hector continues in the field, (the greeks being driven to
their fortifications before the ships,) and gives orders to keep the
watch all night in the camp, to prevent the enemy from re-embarking and
escaping by flight.
they kindle fires through all the fields, and pass
the night under arms.
the time of seven and twenty days is employed from the opening of
the poem to the end of this book.
the scene here (except of the

she shall have her way in the end—hector’s triumph is stayed by

celestial machines) lies in the field towards the seashore.

nightfall—the trojans bivouac on the plain.

aurora now, fair daughter of the dawn,

now when morning, clad in her robe of saffron, had begun to

sprinkled with rosy light the dewy lawn;
when jove convened the senate of the skies,

where high olympus’ cloudy tops arise,
the sire of gods his awful silence broke;

the topmost crest of serrated olympus.

the heavens attentive trembled as he spoke:[189]

then he spoke and all the

“celestial states!
immortal gods!
give ear,

other gods gave ear.

hear our decree, and reverence what ye hear;

“hear me,” said he, “gods and goddesses,
that i may speak even as i am minded.

the fix’d decree which not all heaven can move;

let none of you neither

thou, fate!

goddess nor god try to cross me, but obey me every one of you

fulfil it!

that i may bring this matter to an end.

and, ye powers, approve!

if i see anyone acting

what god but enters yon forbidden field,
who yields assistance, or but wills to yield,

apart and helping either trojans or danaans, he shall be beaten

back to the skies with shame he shall be driven,
gash’d with dishonest wounds, the scorn of heaven;
or far, oh far, from steep olympus thrown,

inordinately ere he come back again to olympus; or i will hurl

low in the dark tartarean gulf shall groan,

him down into dark tartarus far into the deepest pit under the

with burning chains fix’d to the brazen floors,
and lock’d by hell’s inexorable doors;

earth, where the gates are iron and the floor bronze, as far

as deep beneath the infernal centre hurl’d,[190]
as from that centre to the ethereal world.

beneath hades as heaven is high above the earth, that you may

let him who tempts me, dread those dire abodes:
and know, the almighty is the god of gods.
league all your forces, then, ye powers above,

learn how much the mightiest i am among you.

join all, and try the omnipotence of jove.

try me and find out

let down our golden everlasting chain[191]

for yourselves.

whose strong embrace holds heaven, and earth, and main

hangs me a golden chain from heaven, and lay hold

strive all, of mortal and immortal birth,

of it all of you, gods and goddesses together—tug as you will,

to drag, by this, the thunderer down to earth:

you will not drag jove the supreme counsellor from heaven to

ye strive in vain!
if i but stretch this hand,

earth; but were i to pull at it myself i should draw you up with

i heave the gods, the ocean, and the land;
i fix the chain to great olympus’ height,

earth and sea into the bargain, then would i bind the chain about

and the vast world hangs trembling in my sight!

some pinnacle of olympus and leave you all dangling in the mid

for such i reign, unbounded and above;

firmament.

and such are men, and gods, compared to jove.

so far am i above all others either of gods or men.

”

”

the all-mighty spoke, nor durst the powers reply:
a reverend horror silenced all the sky;
trembling they stood before their sovereign’s look;

they were frightened and all of them of held their peace, for he

at length his best-beloved, the power of wisdom, spoke:
“o first and greatest!

god, by gods adored

but, ah!
permit to pity human state:

to be gainsaid, but we are also sorry for the danaan warriors,

if not to help, at least lament their fate.

who are perishing and coming to a bad end.

from fields forbidden we submiss refrain,

we will, however,

with arms unaiding mourn our argives slain;

since you so bid us, refrain from actual fighting, but we will

yet grant my counsels still their breasts may move,

make serviceable suggestions to the argives that they may not all

or all must perish in the wrath of jove.

of them perish in your displeasure.

”

”

the cloud-compelling god her suit approved,
and smiled superior on his best beloved;

”

brass were their hoofs, their curling manes of gold:

of heaven’s undrossy gold the gods array,

refulgent, flash’d intolerable day.

the body, seized his gold whip and took his seat in his chariot.

high on the throne he shines: his coursers fly

thereon he lashed his horses and they flew forward nothing loth

between the extended earth and starry sky.

midway twixt earth and starry heaven.

but when to ida’s topmost height he came,

after a while he reached

(fair nurse of fountains, and of savage game,)
where o’er her pointed summits proudly raised,

many-fountained ida, mother of wild beasts, and gargarus, where

his fane breathed odours, and his altar blazed:

are his grove and fragrant altar.

there, from his radiant car, the sacred sire
of gods and men released the steeds of fire:

there the father of gods and

blue ambient mists the immortal steeds embraced;

men stayed his horses, took them from the chariot, and hid them

high on the cloudy point his seat he placed;
thence his broad eye the subject world surveys,

in a thick cloud; then he took his seat all glorious upon the

the town, and tents, and navigable seas.

topmost crests, looking down upon the city of troy and the ships
of the achaeans.

now had the grecians snatch’d a short repast,

the achaeans took their morning meal hastily at the ships, and

and buckled on their shining arms with haste.

afterwards put on their armour.

troy roused as soon; for on this dreadful day

the trojans on the other hand

the fate of fathers, wives, and infants lay.

likewise armed themselves throughout the city, fewer in numbers
but nevertheless eager perforce to do battle for their wives and
children.

the gates unfolding pour forth all their train;

all the gates were flung wide open, and horse and foot

squadrons on squadrons cloud the dusky plain:
men, steeds, and chariots shake the trembling ground,
the tumult thickens, and the skies resound;

sallied forth with the tramp as of a great multitude.

and now with shouts the shocking armies closed,

when they were got together in one place, shield clashed with

to lances lances, shields to shields opposed,

shield, and spear with spear, in the conflict of mail-clad men.

host against host with shadowy legends drew,
the sounding darts in iron tempests flew;

mighty was the din as the bossed shields pressed hard on one

victors and vanquish’d join promiscuous cries,
triumphant shouts and dying groans arise;

another—death—cry and shout of triumph of slain and slayers, and

with streaming blood the slippery fields are dyed,
and slaughter’d heroes swell the dreadful tide.

the earth ran red with blood.

long as the morning beams, increasing bright,
o’er heaven’s clear azure spread the sacred light,

now so long as the day waxed and it was still morning their

commutual death the fate of war confounds,
each adverse battle gored with equal wounds.

weapons beat against one another, and the people fell, but when

but when the sun the height of heaven ascends,

the sun had reached mid-heaven, the sire of all balanced his

the sire of gods his golden scales suspends,[192]
with equal hand: in these explored the fate

golden scales, and put two fates of death within them, one for

of greece and troy, and poised the mighty weight:

the trojans and the other for the achaeans.

press’d with its load, the grecian balance lies

he took the balance
by the middle, and when he lifted it up the day of the achaeans
sank; the death-fraught scale of the achaeans settled down upon

low sunk on earth, the trojan strikes the skies.

the ground, while that of the trojans rose heavenwards.

then jove from ida’s top his horrors spreads;

then he

the clouds burst dreadful o’er the grecian heads;
thick lightnings flash; the muttering thunder rolls;

thundered aloud from ida, and sent the glare of his lightning

their strength he withers, and unmans their souls.
before his wrath the trembling hosts retire;

upon the achaeans; when they saw this, pale fear fell upon them

the gods in terrors, and the skies on fire.

and they were sore afraid.

nor great idomeneus that sight could bear,

idomeneus dared not stay nor yet agamemnon, nor did the two

nor each stern ajax, thunderbolts of war:

ajaxes, servants of mars, hold their ground.

nor he, the king of war, the alarm sustain’d

nestor knight of

nestor alone, amidst the storm remain’d.
unwilling he remain’d, for paris’ dart

“whither, oh whither does ulysses run?

to, with your back turned like a coward?

”

but bold tydides to the rescue goes,

thy veins no more with ancient vigour glow,

hard, your force is spent, and age is heavy upon you, your squire

weak is thy servant, and thy coursers slow.

is naught, and your horses are slow to move.

then haste, ascend my seat, and from the car

observe the steeds of tros, renown’d in war.

see what the horses of tros can do—how cleverly they can scud

practised alike to turn, to stop, to chase,
to dare the fight, or urge the rapid race:

hither and thither over the plain either in flight or in pursuit.

these late obey’d æneas’ guiding rein;

i took them from the hero aeneas.

leave thou thy chariot to our faithful train;

let our squires attend to your

with these against yon trojans will we go,
nor shall great hector want an equal foe;

own steeds, but let us drive mine straight at the trojans, that

fierce as he is, even he may learn to fear
the thirsty fury of my flying spear.

hector may learn how furiously i too can wield my spear.

”

”

thus said the chief; and nestor, skill’d in war,

“o chief!

this day, averse, the sovereign of the skies
assists great hector, and our palm denies.
some other sun may see the happier hour,
when greece shall conquer by his heavenly power.

to-day he vouchsafes victory to hector; to-morrow, if it so

’tis not in man his fix’d decree to move:

please him, he will again grant it to ourselves; no man, however

the great will glory to submit to jove.

brave, may thwart the purpose of jove, for he is far stronger

”

than any.

thy years are awful, and thy words are wise.

are fled;
this arm shall reach thy heart, and stretch thee dead.

your ships, for i shall kill you with my own hand.

”

now fears dissuade him, and now hopes invite.

the son of tydeus was in two minds whether or no to turn his

to stop his coursers, and to stand the fight;

horses round again and fight him.

thrice turn’d the chief, and thrice imperial jove

on ida’s summits thunder’d from above.
great hector heard; he saw the flashing light,

did jove thunder from the heights of ida in token to the trojans

(the sign of conquest,) and thus urged the fight:

that he would turn the battle in their favour.
hector then

“hear, every trojan, lycian, dardan band,

shouted to them and said, “trojans, lycians, and dardanians,

all famed in war, and dreadful hand to hand.

lovers of close fighting, be men, my friends, and fight with

be mindful of the wreaths your arms have won,

might and with main; i see that jove is minded to vouchsafe

your great forefathers’ glories, and your own.
heard ye the voice of jove?
success and fame
await on troy, on greece eternal shame.

victory and great glory to myself, while he will deal destruction

in vain they skulk behind their boasted wall,

upon the danaans.

weak bulwarks; destined by this arm to fall.
high o’er their slighted trench our steeds shall bound,

fools, for having thought of building this weak

and pass victorious o’er the levell’d mound.

and worthless wall.

soon as before yon hollow ships we stand,

it shall not stay my fury; my horses will
spring lightly over their trench, and when i am at their ships

fight each with flames, and toss the blazing brand;
till, their proud navy wrapt in smoke and fires,

forget not to bring me fire that i may burn them, while i

all greece, encompass’d, in one blaze expires.

slaughter the argives who will be all dazed and bewildered by the

”

smoke.
”

furious he said; then bending o’er the yoke,

“now, xanthus, æthon, lampus, urge the chase,
and thou, podargus!

then he cried to his horses, “xanthus and podargus, and you

prove thy generous race;

and all your master’s well-spent care repay.

this night, this glorious night, the fleet is ours!

”

that heard, deep anguish stung saturnia’s soul;

have to sit there sulking alone on ida.

“o argives!

could be heard afar, he shouted to the danaans, saying, “argives,

where now are all your glorious boasts of yore,

shame on you cowardly creatures, brave in semblance only; where
are now our vaunts that we should prove victorious—the vaunts we
made so vaingloriously in lemnos, when we ate the flesh of horned

your hasty triumphs on the lemnian shore?

cattle and filled our mixing-bowls to the brim?
you vowed that

each fearless hero dares a hundred foes,

you would each of you stand against a hundred or two hundred men,

while the feast lasts, and while the goblet flows;
but who to meet one martial man is found,

and now you prove no match even for one—for hector, who will be

when the fight rages, and the flames surround?

ere long setting our ships in a blaze.

o mighty jove!

father jove, did you ever

o sire of the distress’d!
was ever king like me, like me oppress’d?
with power immense, with justice arm’d in vain;
my glory ravish’d, and my people slain!

so ruin a great king and rob him so utterly of his greatness?

to thee my vows were breathed from every shore;

yet, when to my sorrow i was coming hither, i never let my ship

what altar smoked not with our victims’ gore?

pass your altars without offering the fat and thigh-bones of

with fat of bulls i fed the constant flame,

heifers upon every one of them, so eager was i to sack the city

and ask’d destruction to the trojan name.
now, gracious god!

of troy.

far humbler our demand;

vouchsafe me then this prayer—suffer us to escape at any

give these at least to ’scape from hector’s hand,

rate with our lives, and let not the achaeans be so utterly

and save the relics of the grecian land!

vanquished by the trojans.

”

”

thus pray’d the king, and heaven’s great father heard

thus did he pray, and father jove pitying his tears vouchsafed

his vows, in bitterness of soul preferr’d:
the wrath appeased, by happy signs declares,
and gives the people to their monarch’s prayers.

him that his people should live, not die; forthwith he sent them

his eagle, sacred bird of heaven!

an eagle, most unfailingly portentous of all birds, with a young

he sent,

)

which the achaeans sacrificed to jove the lord of omens; when,

therefore, the people saw that the bird had come from jove, they

and fierce on troy with doubled fury drive.

the dart drove on, and issued at his breast:

went right through his chest, and his armour rang rattling round

headlong he quits the car: his arms resound;
his ponderous buckler thunders on the ground.

him as he fell forward from his chariot.

forth rush a tide of greeks, the passage freed;

the atridae first, the ajaces next succeed:

evaemon’s son next issues to the foe,

the brave son of euaemon.

and last young teucer with his bended bow.

ninth came teucer with his bow, and

secure behind the telamonian shield

took his place under cover of the shield of ajax son of telamon.

the skilful archer wide survey’d the field,

when ajax lifted his shield teucer would peer round, and when he

with every shaft some hostile victim slew,
then close beneath the sevenfold orb withdrew:

had hit any one in the throng, the man would fall dead; then

the conscious infant so, when fear alarms,
retires for safety to the mother’s arms.
thus ajax guards his brother in the field,

teucer would hie back to ajax as a child to its mother, and again

moves as he moves, and turns the shining shield.

duck down under his shield.

who first by teucer’s mortal arrows bled?

which of the trojans did brave teucer first kill?

orsilochus; then fell ormenus dead:

orsilochus, and

the godlike lycophon next press’d the plain,
with chromius, daetor, ophelestes slain:

then ormenus and ophelestes, daetor, chromius, and godlike

bold hamopaon breathless sunk to ground;

lycophontes, amopaon son of polyaemon, and melanippus.

the bloody pile great melanippus crown’d.

all these

heaps fell on heaps, sad trophies of his art,

in turn did he lay low upon the earth, and king agamemnon was

a trojan ghost attending every dart.
great agamemnon views with joyful eye
the ranks grow thinner as his arrows fly:

glad when he saw him making havoc of the trojans with his mighty

“o youth forever dear!
(the monarch cried)

bow.

thus, always thus, thy early worth be tried;

he went up to him and said, “teucer, man after my own heart,

thy brave example shall retrieve our host,

son of telamon, captain among the host, shoot on, and be at once

thy country’s saviour, and thy father’s boast!

the saving of the danaans and the glory of your father telamon,

sprung from an alien’s bed thy sire to grace,

who brought you up and took care of you in his own house when you

the vigorous offspring of a stolen embrace:

were a child, bastard though you were.

proud of his boy, he own’d the generous flame,
and the brave son repays his cares with fame.

cover him with glory

now hear a monarch’s vow: if heaven’s high powers

though he is far off; i will promise and i will assuredly

give me to raze troy’s long-defended towers;
whatever treasures greece for me design,

perform; if aegis-bearing jove and minerva grant me to sack the

the next rich honorary gift be thine:

city of ilius, you shall have the next best meed of honour after

some golden tripod, or distinguished car,
with coursers dreadful in the ranks of war:
or some fair captive, whom thy eyes approve,

my own—a tripod, or two horses with their chariot, or a woman who

shall recompense the warrior’s toils with love.

shall go up into your bed.

”

”

to this the chief: “with praise the rest inspire,
nor urge a soul already fill’d with fire.

and teucer answered, “most noble son of atreus, you need not urge

what strength i have, be now in battle tried,
till every shaft in phrygian blood be dyed.
since rallying from our wall we forced the foe,

me; from the moment we began to drive them back to ilius, i have

still aim’d at hector have i bent my bow:

never ceased so far as in me lies to look out for men whom i can

eight forky arrows from this hand have fled,
and eight bold heroes by their points lie dead:
but sure some god denies me to destroy

shoot and kill; i have shot eight barbed shafts, and all of them

this fury of the field, this dog of troy.

have been buried in the flesh of warlike youths, but this mad dog

”

i cannot hit.
”

he said, and twang’d the string.

as he spoke he aimed another arrow straight at hector, for he was

the weapon flies
at hector’s breast, and sings along the skies:
he miss’d the mark; but pierced gorgythio’s heart,

bent on hitting him; nevertheless he missed him, and the arrow

and drench’d in royal blood the thirsty dart.

hit priam’s brave son gorgythion in the breast.

(fair castianira, nymph of form divine,
this offspring added to king priam’s line.
)

his mother, fair

as full-blown poppies, overcharged with rain,[196]

castianeira, lovely as a goddess, had been married from aesyme,

decline the head, and drooping kiss the plain;

and now he bowed his head as a garden poppy in full bloom when it

so sinks the youth: his beauteous head, depress’d

is weighed down by showers in spring—even thus heavy bowed his

beneath his helmet, drops upon his breast.

head beneath the weight of his helmet.

another shaft the raging archer drew,
that other shaft with erring fury flew,
(from hector, phœbus turn’d the flying wound,)

again he aimed at hector, for he was longing to hit him, and

yet fell not dry or guiltless to the ground:

again his arrow missed, for apollo turned it aside; but he hit

thy breast, brave archeptolemus!

hector with grief his charioteer beheld

stone made straight for teucer with intent to kill him.

the youth already strain’d the forceful yew;

teucer

the shaft already to his shoulder drew;

had just taken an arrow from his quiver and had laid it upon the

touch’d where the neck and hollow chest unite;
there, where the juncture knits the channel bone,

just where the collar-bone divides the neck from the chest, a

the furious chief discharged the craggy stone:

very deadly place, and broke the sinew of his arm so that his

the bow-string burst beneath the ponderous blow,

wrist was less, and the bow dropped from his hand as he fell

and his numb’d hand dismiss’d his useless bow.

forward on his knees.

he fell: but ajax his broad shield display’d,
and screen’d his brother with the mighty shade;

ajax saw that his brother had fallen, and

till great alaster, and mecistheus, bore

the batter’d archer groaning to the shore.

shield.

troy yet found grace before the olympian sire,

in his great pain.

the greeks repulsed, retreat behind their wall,

jove now again put heart into the trojans, and they drove the

or in the trench on heaps confusedly fall.
first of the foe, great hector march’d along,

achaeans to their deep trench with hector in all his glory at

with terror clothed, and more than mortal strong.

their head.

as the bold hound, that gives the lion chase,

as a hound grips a wild boar or lion in flank or

with beating bosom, and with eager pace,
hangs on his haunch, or fastens on his heels,

buttock when he gives him chase, and watches warily for his

guards as he turns, and circles as he wheels;
thus oft the grecians turn’d, but still they flew;
thus following, hector still the hindmost slew.

wheeling, even so did hector follow close upon the achaeans, ever

when flying they had pass’d the trench profound,

killing the hindmost as they rushed panic-stricken onwards.
when

and many a chief lay gasping on the ground;

they had fled through the set stakes and trench and many achaeans

before the ships a desperate stand they made,

their ships, calling upon one another and praying every man

and fired the troops, and called the gods to aid.

instantly as they lifted up their hands to the gods; but hector

fierce on his rattling chariot hector came:
his eyes like gorgon shot a sanguine flame
that wither’d all their host: like mars he stood:

wheeled his horses this way and that, his eyes glaring like those

dire as the monster, dreadful as the god!

of gorgo or murderous mars.

their strong distress the wife of jove survey’d;

then pensive thus, to war’s triumphant maid:
“o daughter of that god, whose arm can wield
the avenging bolt, and shake the sable shield!

minerva, “alas, child of aegis-bearing jove, shall you and i take

now, in this moment of her last despair,
shall wretched greece no more confess our care,
condemn’d to suffer the full force of fate,
and drain the dregs of heaven’s relentless hate?

no more thought for the dying danaans, though it be the last time

gods!

we ever do so?

what numbers fell!

the onset of but a single man.

hector the son of priam rages with

intolerable fury, and has already done great mischief.

”

”

so spake the imperial regent of the skies;
to whom the goddess with the azure eyes:
“long since had hector stain’d these fields with gore,

minerva answered, “would, indeed, this fellow might die in his

stretch’d by some argive on his native shore:
but he above, the sire of heaven, withstands,

own land, and fall by the hands of the achaeans; but my father

mocks our attempts, and slights our just demands;

jove is mad with spleen, ever foiling me, ever headstrong and

the stubborn god, inflexible and hard,

unjust.

forgets my service and deserved reward:
saved i, for this, his favourite son distress’d,

proud tyrants humbles, and whole hosts o’erturns.

juno

saturnia lends the lash; the coursers fly;

heaven’s gates spontaneous open to the powers,

“thaumantia!

mount the winds, and stop their car;

iris, turn them back, and see that they do not come near me, for

against the highest who shall wage the war?
if furious yet they dare the vain debate,

if we come to fighting there will be mischief.

thus have i spoke, and what i speak is fate:

this is what i
say, and this is what i mean to do.

their coursers crush’d beneath the wheels shall lie,

”

”

then, mounting on the pinions of the wind,
she flew; and juno thus her rage resign’d:

with this she left them, and juno said to minerva, “of a truth,

“o daughter of that god, whose arm can wield
the avenging bolt, and shake the saber shield!

child of aegis-bearing jove, i am not for fighting men’s battles

no more let beings of superior birth
contend with jove for this low race of earth;
triumphant now, now miserably slain,

further in defiance of jove.

they breathe or perish as the fates ordain:

let them live or die as luck will

but jove’s high counsels full effect shall find;

have it, and let jove mete out his judgements upon the trojans

and, ever constant, ever rule mankind.

and danaans according to his own pleasure.

”

”

she spoke, and backward turn’d her steeds of light,
adorn’d with manes of gold, and heavenly bright.
the hours unloosed them, panting as they stood,

she turned her steeds; the hours presently unyoked them, made

and heap’d their mangers with ambrosial food.

the assembly of gods.

and wide beneath him all olympus shakes.

reeled beneath him.

trembling afar the offending powers appear’d,

minerva and juno sat alone, apart from jove,

confused and silent, for his frown they fear’d.

and neither spoke nor asked him questions, but jove knew what

he saw their soul, and thus his word imparts:
“pallas and juno!
say, why heave your hearts?

they meant, and said, “minerva and juno, why are you so angry?

soon was your battle o’er: proud troy retired
before your face, and in your wrath expired.

are you fatigued with killing so many of your dear friends the

but know, whoe’er almighty power withstand!

trojans?

unmatch’d our force, unconquer’d is our hand:
who shall the sovereign of the skies control?

be this as it may, such is the might of my hands that

not all the gods that crown the starry pole.

all the gods in olympus cannot turn me; you were both of you

your hearts shall tremble, if our arms we take,

trembling all over ere ever you saw the fight and its terrible

and each immortal nerve with horror shake.

doings.

for thus i speak, and what i speak shall stand;

i tell you therefore-and it would have surely been—i

what power soe’er provokes our lifted hand,

should have struck you with lightning, and your chariots would

on this our hill no more shall hold his place;
cut off, and exiled from the ethereal race.

never have brought you back again to olympus.

”

lest all should perish in the rage of jove.

they may not all of them perish in your displeasure.

it or no, this is how it is decreed; for aught i care, you may go

fly, if thy wilt, to earth’s remotest bound,
where on her utmost verge the seas resound;
where cursed iapetus and saturn dwell,

to the lowest depths beneath earth and sea, where iapetus and

fast by the brink, within the streams of hell;
no sun e’er gilds the gloomy horrors there;

saturn dwell in lone tartarus with neither ray of light nor

no cheerful gales refresh the lazy air:

breath of wind to cheer them.

there arm once more the bold titanian band;

you may go on and on till you get

and arm in vain; for what i will, shall stand.

there, and i shall not care one whit for your displeasure; you
are the greatest vixen living.

”

”
juno made him no answer.

wounds, that long hence may ask their spouses’ care.

their ships hither.

and prostrate heroes bleed around their lord.

the first to fall and many another of his comrades round him.

certain as this, oh!
might my days endure,
from age inglorious, and black death secure;
so might my life and glory know no bound,

would that i were as sure of being immortal and never growing

like pallas worshipp’d, like the sun renown’d!
as the next dawn, the last they shall enjoy,

old, and of being worshipped like minerva and apollo, as i am

shall crush the greeks, and end the woes of troy.

that this day will bring evil to the argives.

the leader spoke.

the troops exulting sat in order round,

thus
high in hope they sat through the livelong night by the highways

and beaming fires illumined all the ground.

of war, and many a watchfire did they kindle.

as when the moon, refulgent lamp of night,[198]

as when the stars

o’er heaven’s pure azure spreads her sacred light,
when not a breath disturbs the deep serene,

shine clear, and the moon is bright—there is not a breath of air,

and not a cloud o’ercasts the solemn scene,

not a peak nor glade nor jutting headland but it stands out in

around her throne the vivid planets roll,

the ineffable radiance that breaks from the serene of heaven; the

and stars unnumber’d gild the glowing pole,
o’er the dark trees a yellower verdure shed,
and tip with silver every mountain’s head:

stars can all of them be told and the heart of the shepherd is

then shine the vales, the rocks in prospect rise,
a flood of glory bursts from all the skies:
the conscious swains, rejoicing in the sight,
eye the blue vault, and bless the useful light.
so many flames before proud ilion blaze,
and lighten glimmering xanthus with their rays.
the long reflections of the distant fires

glad—even thus shone the watchfires of the trojans before ilius

gleam on the walls, and tremble on the spires.

midway between the ships and the river xanthus.

a thousand piles the dusky horrors gild,

a thousand

and shoot a shady lustre o’er the field.
full fifty guards each flaming pile attend,
whose umber’d arms, by fits, thick flashes send,

camp-fires gleamed upon the plain, and in the glow of each there

[illustration: ] the shield of achilles
book ix.
argument.

book ix.

the embassy to achilles.

the embassy to achilles.
thus did the trojans watch.

agamemnon, after the last day’s defeat, proposes to the greeks to quit

but panic, comrade of blood-stained

the siege, and return to their country.
diomed opposes this, and nestor
seconds him, praising his wisdom and resolution.
he orders the guard to
be strengthened, and a council summoned to deliberate what measures are
to be followed in this emergency.
agamemnon pursues this advice, and
nestor further prevails upon him to send ambassadors to achilles, in
order to move him to a reconciliation.
ulysses and ajax are made choice
of, who are accompanied by old phœnix.
they make, each of them, very
moving and pressing speeches, but are rejected with roughness by
achilles, who notwithstanding retains phœnix in his tent.
the
ambassadors return unsuccessfully to the camp, and the troops betake
themselves to sleep.
this book, and the next following, take up the space of one night,
which is the twenty-seventh from the beginning of the poem.
the
scene lies on the sea-shore, the station of the grecian ships.
thus joyful troy maintain’d the watch of night;
while fear, pale comrade of inglorious flight,[199]
and heaven-bred horror, on the grecian part,

rout, had taken fast hold of the achaeans, and their princes were

sat on each face, and sadden’d every heart.

all of them in despair.

as from its cloudy dungeon issuing forth,

as when the two winds that blow from

a double tempest of the west and north

thrace—the north and the northwest—spring up of a sudden and

swells o’er the sea, from thracia’s frozen shore,
heaps waves on waves, and bids the ægean roar:

rouse the fury of the main—in a moment the dark waves uprear

this way and that the boiling deeps are toss’d:

their heads and scatter their sea-wrack in all directions—even

such various passions urged the troubled host,

thus troubled were the hearts of the achaeans.

great agamemnon grieved above the rest;
superior sorrows swell’d his royal breast;
himself his orders to the heralds bears,
to bid to council all the grecian peers,

the son of atreus in dismay bade the heralds call the people to a

but bid in whispers: these surround their chief,

council man by man, but not to cry the matter aloud; he made

in solemn sadness and majestic grief.

haste also himself to call them, and they sat sorry at heart in

the king amidst the mournful circle rose:

their assembly.

down his wan cheek a briny torrent flows.

agamemnon shed tears as it were a running stream

so silent fountains, from a rock’s tall head,

or cataract on the side of some sheer cliff; and thus, with many

in sable streams soft-trickling waters shed.
with more than vulgar grief he stood oppress’d;
words, mix’d with sighs, thus bursting from his breast:

a heavy sigh he spoke to the achaeans.

“ye sons of greece!

“my friends,” said he,

partake your leader’s care;
fellows in arms and princes of the war!

“princes and councillors of the argives, the hand of heaven has

of partial jove too justly we complain,

been laid heavily upon me.

and heavenly oracles believed in vain.

cruel jove gave me his solemn promise

a safe return was promised to our toils,

that i should sack the city of troy before returning, but he has

with conquest honour’d and enrich’d with spoils:
now shameful flight alone can save the host;

played me false, and is now bidding me go ingloriously back to

our wealth, our people, and our glory lost.

argos with the loss of much people.

so jove decrees, almighty lord of all!
jove, at whose nod whole empires rise or fall,

such is the will of jove, who

who shakes the feeble props of human trust,

has laid many a proud city in the dust as he will yet lay others,

and towers and armies humbles to the dust.

for his power is above all.

haste then, for ever quit these fatal fields,

now, therefore, let us all do as i

haste to the joys our native country yields;
spread all your canvas, all your oars employ,

say and sail back to our own country, for we shall not take

nor hope the fall of heaven-defended troy.

troy.

”

”

he said: deep silence held the grecian band;

thus he spoke, and the sons of the achaeans for a long while sat

silent, unmov’d in dire dismay they stand;

sorrowful there, but they all held their peace, till at last

a pensive scene!
till tydeus’ warlike son
roll’d on the king his eyes, and thus begun:
“when kings advise us to renounce our fame,
first let him speak who first has suffer’d shame.

diomed of the loud battle-cry made answer saying, “son of atreus,

if i oppose thee, prince!

i will chide your folly, as is my right in council.

thy wrath withhold,

be not then

the laws of council bid my tongue be bold.

aggrieved that i should do so.

thou first, and thou alone, in fields of fight,

in the first place you attacked me

durst brand my courage, and defame my might:
nor from a friend the unkind reproach appear’d,

before all the danaans and said that i was a coward and no

the greeks stood witness, all our army heard.

soldier.

the gods, o chief!

the argives young and old know that you did so.

from whom our honours spring,

but the

the gods have made thee but by halves a king:

son of scheming saturn endowed you by halves only.

they gave thee sceptres, and a wide command;
they gave dominion o’er the seas and land;

he gave you

the noblest power that might the world control

honour as the chief ruler over us, but valour, which is the

they gave thee not—a brave and virtuous soul.

highest both right and might he did not give you.

is this a general’s voice, that would suggest

sir, think you

fears like his own to every grecian breast?

that the sons of the achaeans are indeed as unwarlike and

confiding in our want of worth, he stands;

cowardly as you say they are?

and if we fly, ’tis what our king commands.

if your own mind is set upon going

go thou, inglorious!

home—go—the way is open to you; the many ships that followed you

from the embattled plain;

from mycene stand ranged upon the sea-shore; but the rest of us

ships thou hast store, and nearest to the main;

stay here till we have sacked troy.

a noble care the grecians shall employ,

nay though these too should

to combat, conquer, and extirpate troy.
here greece shall stay; or, if all greece retire,
myself shall stay, till troy or i expire;
myself, and sthenelus, will fight for fame;

turn homeward with their ships, sthenelus and myself will still

god bade us fight, and ’twas with god we came.

fight on till we reach the goal of ilius, for heaven was with us
when we came.

”

”

he ceased; the greeks loud acclamations raise,

the sons of the achaeans shouted applause at the words of diomed,

and voice to voice resounds tydides’ praise.
wise nestor then his reverend figure rear’d;

and presently nestor rose to speak.

he spoke: the host in still attention heard:[200]
“o truly great!

“son of tydeus,” said he, “in

in whom the gods have join’d

war your prowess is beyond question, and in council you excel all

such strength of body with such force of mind:

who are of your own years; no one of the achaeans can make light

in conduct, as in courage, you excel,
still first to act what you advise so well.
these wholesome counsels which thy wisdom moves,

of what you say nor gainsay it, but you have not yet come to the

applauding greece with common voice approves.

end of the whole matter.

kings thou canst blame; a bold but prudent youth:

you are still young—you might be the

and blame even kings with praise, because with truth.
and yet those years that since thy birth have run
would hardly style thee nestor’s youngest son.
then let me add what yet remains behind,

youngest of my own children—still you have spoken wisely and have

a thought unfinish’d in that generous mind;

counselled the chief of the achaeans not without discretion;

age bids me speak!

nevertheless i am older than you and i will tell you everything;

nor shall the advice i bring
distaste the people, or offend the king:
“cursed is the man, and void of law and right,
unworthy property, unworthy light,
unfit for public rule, or private care,

therefore let no man, not even king agamemnon, disregard my

that wretch, that monster, who delights in war;
whose lust is murder, and whose horrid joy,

saying, for he that foments civil discord is a clanless,

to tear his country, and his kind destroy!

hearthless outlaw.

this night, refresh and fortify thy train;

“now, however, let us obey the behests of night and get our

between the trench and wall let guards remain:

suppers, but let the sentinels every man of them camp by the
trench that is without the wall.

be that the duty of the young and bold;

i am giving these instructions
to the young men; when they have been attended to, do you, son of

but thou, o king, to council call the old;
great is thy sway, and weighty are thy cares;

atreus, give your orders, for you are the most royal among us

thy high commands must spirit all our wars.

all.

with thracian wines recruit thy honour’d guests,

prepare a feast for your councillors; it is right and
reasonable that you should do so; there is abundance of wine in
your tents, which the ships of the achaeans bring from thrace
daily.
you have everything at your disposal wherewith to
entertain guests, and you have many subjects.

for happy counsels flow from sober feasts.

when many are got

wise, weighty counsels aid a state distress’d,
and such a monarch as can choose the best.

together, you can be guided by him whose counsel is wisest—and

see what a blaze from hostile tents aspires,

sorely do we need shrewd and prudent counsel, for the foe has lit

how near our fleet approach the trojan fires!

his watchfires hard by our ships.

who can, unmoved, behold the dreadful light?
what eye beholds them, and can close to-night?

who can be other than dismayed?

this dreadful interval determines all;
to-morrow, troy must flame, or greece must fall.

this night will either be the ruin of our host, or save it.

”

”

thus spoke the hoary sage: the rest obey;

thus did he speak, and they did even as he had said.

swift through the gates the guards direct their way.

the

o king!

“with yourself, most noble son of atreus, king of men, agamemnon,

the counsels of my age attend;
with thee my cares begin, with thee must end.

will i both begin my speech and end it, for you are king over

thee, prince!

much people.

it fits alike to speak and hear,

jove, moreover, has vouchsafed you to wield the

pronounce with judgment, with regard give ear,

sceptre and to uphold righteousness, that you may take thought
for your people under you; therefore it behooves you above all
others both to speak and to give ear, and to out the counsel of
another who shall have been minded to speak wisely.

to see no wholesome motion be withstood,

all turns on

and ratify the best for public good.

you and on your commands, therefore i will say what i think will
be best.

nor, though a meaner give advice, repine,
but follow it, and make the wisdom thine.
hear then a thought, not now conceived in haste,

no man will be of a truer mind than that which has been

at once my present judgment and my past.

mine from the hour when you, sir, angered achilles by taking the
girl briseis from his tent against my judgment.

when from pelides’ tent you forced the maid,

i urged you not

i first opposed, and faithful, durst dissuade;

to do so, but you yielded to your own pride, and dishonoured a

but bold of soul, when headlong fury fired,

hero whom heaven itself had honoured—for you still hold the prize

you wronged the man, by men and gods admired:

that had been awarded to him.

now seek some means his fatal wrath to end,

now, however, let us think how we

with prayers to move him, or with gifts to bend.

may appease him, both with presents and fair speeches that may

conciliate him.
”

to whom the king.

and king agamemnon answered, “sir, you have reproved my folly
justly.

“with justice hast thou shown

i was wrong.

a prince’s faults, and i with reason own.

i own it.

that happy man, whom jove still honours most,

one whom heaven befriends is in

is more than armies, and himself a host.
bless’d in his love, this wondrous hero stands;

himself a host, and jove has shown that he befriends this man by

heaven fights his war, and humbles all our bands.

destroying much people of the achaeans.

fain would my heart, which err’d through frantic rage,

i was blinded with

the wrathful chief and angry gods assuage.

passion and yielded to my worser mind; therefore i will make

if gifts immense his mighty soul can bow,[201]

amends, and will give him great gifts by way of atonement.

hear, all ye greeks, and witness what i vow.

i will
tell them in the presence of you all.

ten weighty talents of the purest gold,

i will give him seven

and twice ten vases of refulgent mould:
seven sacred tripods, whose unsullied frame

tripods that have never yet been on the fire, and ten talents of

yet knows no office, nor has felt the flame;

gold.

twelve steeds unmatch’d in fleetness and in force,

i will give him twenty iron cauldrons and twelve strong

and still victorious in the dusty course;

horses that have won races and carried off prizes.

(rich were the man whose ample stores exceed

rich, indeed,

the prizes purchased by their winged speed;)

both in land and gold is he that has as many prizes as my horses
have won me.

seven lovely captives of the lesbian line,

i will give him seven excellent workwomen, lesbians,

skill’d in each art, unmatch’d in form divine,
the same i chose for more than vulgar charms,
when lesbos sank beneath the hero’s arms:

whom i chose for myself when he took lesbos—all of surpassing

all these, to buy his friendship, shall be paid,

beauty.

and join’d with these the long-contested maid;

i will give him these, and with them her whom i erewhile

with all her charms, briseïs i resign,

took from him, the daughter of briseus; and i swear a great oath

and solemn swear those charms were never mine;
untouch’d she stay’d, uninjured she removes,

that i never went up into her couch, nor have been with her after

pure from my arms, and guiltless of my loves,[202]

the manner of men and women.

these instant shall be his; and if the powers

“all these things will i give him now, and if hereafter the gods

give to our arms proud ilion’s hostile towers,
then shall he store (when greece the spoil divides)

vouchsafe me to sack the city of priam, let him come when we

with gold and brass his loaded navy’s sides:

achaeans are dividing the spoil, and load his ship with gold and

besides, full twenty nymphs of trojan race

bronze to his liking; furthermore let him take twenty trojan

with copious love shall crown his warm embrace,
such as himself will choose; who yield to none,
or yield to helen’s heavenly charms alone.

women, the loveliest after helen herself.

yet hear me further: when our wars are o’er,

then, when we reach

if safe we land on argos’ fruitful shore,

achaean argos, wealthiest of all lands, he shall be my son-in-law

there shall he live my son, our honours share,

and i will show him like honour with my own dear son orestes, who

and with orestes’ self divide my care.

is being nurtured in all abundance.

yet more—three daughters in my court are bred,

i have three daughters,

and each well worthy of a royal bed;
laodice and iphigenia fair,[203]
and bright chrysothemis with golden hair;

chrysothemis, laodice, and iphianassa, let him take the one of

her let him choose whom most his eyes approve,
i ask no presents, no reward for love:

myself will give the dower; so vast a store
as never father gave a child before.

peleus; i will add such dower to boot as no man ever yet gave his

the rich meadows of anthea; aepea also, and the vine-clad slopes

along the verdant margin of the main.

of pedasus, all near the sea, and on the borders of sandy pylos.

there heifers graze, and labouring oxen toil;
bold are the men, and generous is the soil;

the men that dwell there are rich in cattle and sheep; they will

there shall he reign, with power and justice crown’d,

honour him with gifts as though he were a god, and be obedient to

and rule the tributary realms around.

his comfortable ordinances.

all this i give, his vengeance to control,

all this will i do if he will now
forgo his anger.

and sure all this may move his mighty soul.

let him then yield; it is only hades who is

pluto, the grisly god, who never spares,
who feels no mercy, and who hears no prayers,
lives dark and dreadful in deep hell’s abodes,

utterly ruthless and unyielding—and hence he is of all gods the

and mortals hate him, as the worst of gods.

one most hateful to mankind.

great though he be, it fits him to obey,

moreover i am older and more royal

since more than his my years, and more my sway.

than himself.
therefore, let him now obey me.

through the still night they march, and hear the roar
of murmuring billows on the sounding shore.

they went their way by the shore of the sounding sea, and prayed

to neptune, ruler of the seas profound,
whose liquid arms the mighty globe surround,

they pour forth vows, their embassy to bless,
and calm the rage of stern æacides.

“health to achilles!

achilles.

happy are thy guests!

“hail,” said he, “achilles, we have had no scant of good cheer,

not those more honour’d whom atrides feasts:
though generous plenty crown thy loaded boards,
that, agamemnon’s regal tent affords;

neither in the tent of agamemnon, nor yet here; there has been

but greater cares sit heavy on our souls,
nor eased by banquets or by flowing bowls.

plenty to eat and drink, but our thought turns upon no such

what scenes of slaughter in yon fields appear!

matter.

the dead we mourn, and for the living fear;
greece on the brink of fate all doubtful stands,

sir, we are in the face of great disaster, and without

and owns no help but from thy saving hands:

your help know not whether we shall save our fleet or lose it.

troy and her aids for ready vengeance call;

the trojans and their allies have camped hard by our ships and by

their threatening tents already shade our wall:
hear how with shouts their conquest they proclaim,

the wall; they have lit watchfires throughout their host and deem

and point at every ship their vengeful flame!

that nothing can now prevent them from falling on our fleet.

for them the father of the gods declares,
theirs are his omens, and his thunder theirs.

jove, moreover, has sent his lightnings on their right; hector,

see, full of jove, avenging hector rise!

in all his glory, rages like a maniac; confident that jove is

see!

with him he fears neither god nor man, but is gone raving mad,

heaven and earth the raging chief defies;

and prays for the approach of day.

what fury in his breast, what lightning in his eyes!
he waits but for the morn, to sink in flame

he vows that he will hew the

the ships, the greeks, and all the grecian name.

high sterns of our ships in pieces, set fire to their hulls, and

heavens!
how my country’s woes distract my mind,
lest fate accomplish all his rage design’d!

make havoc of the achaeans while they are dazed and smothered in

and must we, gods!

smoke; i much fear that heaven will make good his boasting, and

our heads inglorious lay

it will prove our lot to perish at troy far from our home in

in trojan dust, and this the fatal day?

argos.

return, achilles: oh return, though late,

up, then, and late though it be, save the sons of the

to save thy greeks, and stop the course of fate;

achaeans who faint before the fury of the trojans.

if in that heart or grief or courage lies,

you will

rise to redeem; ah, yet to conquer, rise!
the day may come, when, all our warriors slain,

repent bitterly hereafter if you do not, for when the harm is

that heart shall melt, that courage rise in vain:

done there will be no curing it; consider ere it be too late, and

regard in time, o prince divinely brave!

save the danaans from destruction.

those wholesome counsels which thy father gave.
when peleus in his aged arms embraced

“my good friend, when your father peleus sent you from phthia to

his parting son, these accents were his last:
“‘my child!

agamemnon, did he not charge you saying, ‘son, minerva and juno

with strength, with glory, and success,
thy arms may juno and minerva bless!
trust that to heaven: but thou, thy cares engage
to calm thy passions, and subdue thy rage:

will make you strong if they choose, but check your high temper,

from gentler manners let thy glory grow,

for the better part is in goodwill.

and shun contention, the sure source of woe;

eschew vain quarrelling, and

that young and old may in thy praise combine,

the achaeans old and young will respect you more for doing so.

the virtues of humanity be thine—’

’

this now-despised advice thy father gave;

these were his words, but you have forgotten them.

ah!

even now,

check thy anger; and be truly brave.

however, be appeased, and put away your anger from you.

if thou wilt yield to great atrides’ prayers,

agamemnon
will make you great amends if you will forgive him; listen, and i

gifts worthy thee his royal hand prepares;

will tell you what he has said in his tent that he will give you.

if not—but hear me, while i number o’er

he will give you seven tripods that have never yet been on the

the proffer’d presents, an exhaustless store.
ten weighty talents of the purest gold,
and twice ten vases of refulgent mould;
seven sacred tripods, whose unsullied frame
yet knows no office, nor has felt the flame;
twelve steeds unmatched in fleetness and in force,

fire, and ten talents of gold; twenty iron cauldrons, and twelve

and still victorious in the dusty course;

strong horses that have won races and carried off prizes.

(rich were the man, whose ample stores exceed

rich

the prizes purchased by their winged speed;)

indeed both in land and gold is he who has as many prizes as
these horses have won for agamemnon.
moreover he will give you

seven lovely captives of the lesbian line,
skill’d in each art, unmatch’d in form divine,
the same he chose for more than vulgar charms,

seven excellent workwomen, lesbians, whom he chose for himself,

when lesbos sank beneath thy conquering arms.

when you took lesbos—all of surpassing beauty.

all these, to buy thy friendship shall be paid,

he will give you

and, join’d with these, the long-contested maid;

gone up into her couch nor been with her after the manner of men

pure from his arms, and guiltless of his loves.

and women.

these instant shall be thine; and if the powers

trojan women, the loveliest after helen herself.

”

then thus the goddess-born: “ulysses, hear
a faithful speech, that knows nor art nor fear;
what in my secret soul is understood,
my tongue shall utter, and my deeds make good.

achilles answered, “ulysses, noble son of laertes, i should give

let greece then know, my purpose i retain:

you formal notice plainly and in all fixity of purpose that there

nor with new treaties vex my peace in vain.

be no more of this cajoling, from whatsoever quarter it may come.

who dares think one thing, and another tell,
my heart detests him as the gates of hell.

him do i hate even as the gates of hell who says one thing while

“then thus in short my fix’d resolves attend,

he hides another in his heart; therefore i will say what i mean.

which nor atrides nor his greeks can bend;

i will be appeased neither by agamemnon son of atreus nor by any

long toils, long perils in their cause i bore,
but now the unfruitful glories charm no more.

other of the danaans, for i see that i have no thanks for all my

fight or not fight, a like reward we claim,

fighting.
he that fights fares no better than he that does not;

the wretch and hero find their prize the same.

coward and hero are held in equal honour, and death deals like

alike regretted in the dust he lies,
who yields ignobly, or who bravely dies.

measure to him who works and him who is idle.

of all my dangers, all my glorious pains,

i have taken

a life of labours, lo!
what fruit remains?

nothing by all my hardships—with my life ever in my hand; as a

as the bold bird her helpless young attends,
from danger guards them, and from want defends;
in search of prey she wings the spacious air,
and with the untasted food supplies her care:

bird when she has found a morsel takes it to her nestlings, and

for thankless greece such hardships have i braved,

herself fares hardly, even so many a long night have i been
wakeful, and many a bloody battle have i waged by day against

her wives, her infants, by my labours saved;

those who were fighting for their women.

long sleepless nights in heavy arms i stood,

with my ships i have

and sweat laborious days in dust and blood.
i sack’d twelve ample cities on the main,[207]
and twelve lay smoking on the trojan plain:
then at atrides’ haughty feet were laid

taken twelve cities, and eleven round about troy have i stormed

the wealth i gathered, and the spoils i made.
your mighty monarch these in peace possess’d;

with my men by land; i took great store of wealth from every one

some few my soldiers had, himself the rest.

of them, but i gave all up to agamemnon son of atreus.

some present, too, to every prince was paid;

he stayed

and every prince enjoys the gift he made:

where he was by his ships, yet of what came to him he gave

i only must refund, of all his train;

little, and kept much himself.

see what pre-eminence our merits gain!

“nevertheless he did distribute some meeds of honour among the

my spoil alone his greedy soul delights:

chieftains and kings, and these have them still; from me alone of

my spouse alone must bless his lustful nights:

the achaeans did he take the woman in whom i delighted—let him

the woman, let him (as he may) enjoy;

keep her and sleep with her.

but what’s the quarrel, then, of greece to troy?

why, pray, must the argives needs
fight the trojans?

what to these shores the assembled nations draws,

what made the son of atreus gather the host
and bring them?

what calls for vengeance but a woman’s cause?

was it not for the sake of helen?

are fair endowments and a beauteous face

are the sons of

beloved by none but those of atreus’ race?
the wife whom choice and passion doth approve,

atreus the only men in the world who love their wives?

sure every wise and worthy man will love.

any man of
common right feeling will love and cherish her who is his own, as
i this woman, with my whole heart, though she was but a fruitling

nor did my fair one less distinction claim;

of my spear.

slave as she was, my soul adored the dame.

agamemnon has taken her from me; he has played me

wrong’d in my love, all proffers i disdain;
deceived for once, i trust not kings again.

false; i know him; let him tempt me no further, for he shall not

ye have my answer—what remains to do,

move me.

your king, ulysses, may consult with you.

let him look to you, ulysses, and to the other princes

what needs he the defence this arm can make?

to save his ships from burning.

has he not walls no human force can shake?

he has done much without me

has he not fenced his guarded navy round

already.

with piles, with ramparts, and a trench profound?

he has built a wall; he has dug a trench deep and wide

and will not these (the wonders he has done)

all round it, and he has planted it within with stakes; but even

repel the rage of priam’s single son?

so he stays not the murderous might of hector.

there was a time (’twas when for greece i fought)

he tried it once, and scarce was saved by fate.

but now those ancient enmities are o’er;

then shall you see our parting vessels crown’d,

gods; i will draw my ships into the water and then victual them

ships on the hellespont, and my men rowing out to sea with might

and hear with oars the hellespont resound.

and main.

the third day hence shall pythia greet our sails,[208]
if mighty neptune send propitious gales;

if great neptune vouchsafes me a fair passage, in three

pythia to her achilles shall restore

days i shall be in phthia.

the wealth he left for this detested shore:

i have much there that i left behind

thither the spoils of this long war shall pass,

me when i came here to my sorrow, and i shall bring back still

the ruddy gold, the steel, and shining brass:

further store of gold, of red copper, of fair women, and of iron,

my beauteous captives thither i’ll convey,
and all that rests of my unravish’d prey.
one only valued gift your tyrant gave,

my share of the spoils that we have taken; but one prize, he who

and that resumed—the fair lyrnessian slave.

gave has insolently taken away.

then tell him: loud, that all the greeks may hear,

tell him all as i now bid you,

and learn to scorn the wretch they basely fear;

and tell him in public that the achaeans may hate him and beware

(for arm’d in impudence, mankind he braves,

of him should he think that he can yet dupe others for his

and meditates new cheats on all his slaves;

effrontery never fails him.

though shameless as he is, to face these eyes
is what he dares not: if he dares he dies;)

“as for me, hound that he is, he dares not look me in the face.

tell him, all terms, all commerce i decline,

i

nor share his council, nor his battle join;

will take no counsel with him, and will undertake nothing in
common with him.

for once deceiv’d, was his; but twice were mine,

he has wronged me and deceived me enough, he

no—let the stupid prince, whom jove deprives

shall not cozen me further; let him go his own way, for jove has

of sense and justice, run where frenzy drives;

robbed him of his reason.

his gifts are hateful: kings of such a kind

i loathe his presents, and for himself

stand but as slaves before a noble mind,

care not one straw.

not though he proffer’d all himself possess’d,

he may offer me ten or even twenty times what
he has now done, nay—not though it be all that he has in the

and all his rapine could from others wrest:

world, both now or ever shall have; he may promise me the wealth

not all the golden tides of wealth that crown
the many-peopled orchomenian town;[209]
not all proud thebes’ unrivall’d walls contain,
the world’s great empress on the egyptian plain

of orchomenus or of egyptian thebes, which is the richest city in

(that spreads her conquests o’er a thousand states,
and pours her heroes through a hundred gates,
two hundred horsemen and two hundred cars
from each wide portal issuing to the wars);[210]

the whole world, for it has a hundred gates through each of which

though bribes were heap’d on bribes, in number more

two hundred men may drive at once with their chariots and horses;

than dust in fields, or sands along the shore;

he may offer me gifts as the sands of the sea or the dust of the

should all these offers for my friendship call,

plain in multitude, but even so he shall not move me till i have

’tis he that offers, and i scorn them all.

been revenged in full for the bitter wrong he has done me.
i will

atrides’ daughter never shall be led

not marry his daughter; she may be fair as venus, and skilful as

(an ill-match’d consort) to achilles’ bed;
like golden venus though she charm’d the heart,

minerva, but i will have none of her: let another take her, who

and vied with pallas in the works of art;
some greater greek let those high nuptials grace,
i hate alliance with a tyrant’s race.

may be a good match for her and who rules a larger kingdom.

if heaven restore me to my realms with life,

if

the reverend peleus shall elect my wife;

the gods spare me to return home, peleus will find me a wife;

thessalian nymphs there are of form divine,

there are achaean women in hellas and phthia, daughters of kings

and kings that sue to mix their blood with mine.
bless’d in kind love, my years shall glide away,

that have cities under them; of these i can take whom i will and

content with just hereditary sway;

marry her.

there, deaf for ever to the martial strife,

many a time was i minded when at home in phthia to woo

enjoy the dear prerogative of life.

and wed a woman who would make me a suitable wife, and to enjoy

life is not to be bought with heaps of gold.

the riches of my old father peleus.
my life is more to me than

not all apollo’s pythian treasures hold,

all the wealth of ilius while it was yet at peace before the

stone floor of apollo’s temple beneath the cliffs of pytho.

lost herds and treasures we by arms regain,
and steeds unrivall’d on the dusty plain:

cattle and sheep are to be had for harrying, and a man buy both

but from our lips the vital spirit fled,

tripods and horses if he wants them, but when his life has once

returns no more to wake the silent dead.

left him it can neither be bought nor harried back again.

my fates long since by thetis were disclosed,

“my mother thetis tells me that there are two ways in which i may

and each alternate, life or fame, proposed;

meet my end.

here, if i stay, before the trojan town,

if i stay here and fight, i shall not return alive

short is my date, but deathless my renown:
if i return, i quit immortal praise

but my name will live for ever: whereas if i go home my name will

for years on years, and long-extended days.
convinced, though late, i find my fond mistake,

die, but it will be long ere death shall take me.

and warn the greeks the wiser choice to make;

to the rest of

to quit these shores, their native seats enjoy,

you, then, i say, ‘go home, for you will not take ilius.

nor hope the fall of heaven-defended troy.

has held his hand over her to protect her, and her people have

taken heart.

ye find, achilles is unconquer’d still.

have now hit upon may not be.

but here this night let reverend phœnix stay:
his tedious toils and hoary hairs demand
a peaceful death in pythia’s friendly land.

as for phoenix, let him sleep here

but whether he remain or sail with me,

that he may sail with me in the morning if he so will.
but i will

his age be sacred, and his will be free.

not take him by force.

”

the son of peleus ceased: the chiefs around
in silence wrapt, in consternation drown’d,
attend the stern reply.

they all held their peace, dismayed at the sternness with which

then phœnix rose;

he had denied them, till presently the old knight phoenix in his

(down his white beard a stream of sorrow flows;)
and while the fate of suffering greece he mourn’d,

great fear for the ships of the achaeans, burst into tears and

with accent weak these tender words return’d.
[illustration: ] proserpine
“divine achilles!
wilt thou then retire,

said, “noble achilles, if you are now minded to return, and in

and leave our hosts in blood, our fleets on fire?
if wrath so dreadful fill thy ruthless mind,

the fierceness of your anger will do nothing to save the ships

how shall thy friend, thy phœnix, stay behind?

from burning, how, my son, can i remain here without you?

the royal peleus, when from pythia’s coast

your

he sent thee early to the achaian host;
thy youth as then in sage debates unskill’d,

father peleus bade me go with you when he sent you as a mere lad

and new to perils of the direful field:

from phthia to agamemnon.

he bade me teach thee all the ways of war,

you knew nothing neither of war nor of

to shine in councils, and in camps to dare.

the arts whereby men make their mark in council, and he sent me
with you to train you in all excellence of speech and action.

never, ah, never let me leave thy side!
no time shall part us, and no fate divide,

therefore, my son, i will not stay here without you—no, not

not though the god, that breathed my life, restore
the bloom i boasted, and the port i bore,

though heaven itself vouchsafe to strip my years from off me, and

when greece of old beheld my youthful flames

make me young as i was when i first left hellas the land of fair

(delightful greece, the land of lovely dames),

women.

my father faithless to my mother’s arms,

i was then flying the anger of father amyntor, son of

old as he was, adored a stranger’s charms.

ormenus, who was furious with me in the matter of his concubine,
of whom he was enamoured to the wronging of his wife my mother.

i tried what youth could do (at her desire)

my mother, therefore, prayed me without ceasing to lie with the

to win the damsel, and prevent my sire.

woman myself, that so she hate my father, and in the course of
time i yielded.

my sire with curses loads my hated head,

but my father soon came to know, and cursed me

and cries, ‘ye furies!

bitterly, calling the dread erinyes to witness.

barren be his bed.
’

he prayed that no

infernal jove, the vengeful fiends below,

son of mine might ever sit upon knees—and the gods, jove of the

and ruthless proserpine, confirm’d his vow.
despair and grief distract my labouring mind!
