gods!

i took

what a crime my impious heart design’d!

counsel to kill him, but some god stayed my rashness and bade me

i thought (but some kind god that thought suppress’d)

think on men’s evil tongues and how i should be branded as the

to plunge the poniard in my father’s breast;

murderer of my father; nevertheless i could not bear to stay in
my father’s house with him so bitter against me.

then meditate my flight: my friends in vain

my cousins and

with prayers entreat me, and with force detain.

clansmen came about me, and pressed me sorely to remain; many a

on fat of rams, black bulls, and brawny swine,

sheep and many an ox did they slaughter, and many a fat hog did

they daily feast, with draughts of fragrant wine;

they set down to roast before the fire; many a jar, too, did they
broach of my father’s wine.

strong guards they placed, and watch’d nine nights entire;

nine whole nights did they set a

the roofs and porches flamed with constant fire.

guard over me taking it in turns to watch, and they kept a fire
always burning, both in the cloister of the outer court and in

the tenth, i forced the gates, unseen of all:

the inner court at the doors of the room wherein i lay; but when
the darkness of the tenth night came, i broke through the closed

and, favour’d by the night, o’erleap’d the wall,

doors of my room, and climbed the wall of the outer court after

my travels thence through spacious greece extend;

passing quickly and unperceived through the men on guard and the

in phthia’s court at last my labours end.

women servants.
i then fled through hellas till i came to fertile

your sire received me, as his son caress’d,

phthia, mother of sheep, and to king peleus, who made me welcome
and treated me as a father treats an only son who will be heir to

with gifts enrich’d, and with possessions bless’d.

all his wealth.

the strong dolopians thenceforth own’d my reign,

he made me rich and set me over much people,
establishing me on the borders of phthia where i was chief ruler

and all the coast that runs along the main.

over the dolopians.

by love to thee his bounties i repaid,
and early wisdom to thy soul convey’d:
great as thou art, my lessons made thee brave:
a child i took thee, but a hero gave.
thy infant breast a like affection show’d;

“it was i, achilles, who had the making of you; i loved you with

still in my arms (an ever-pleasing load)

all my heart: for you would eat neither at home nor when you had

or at my knee, by phœnix wouldst thou stand;

gone out elsewhere, till i had first set you upon my knees, cut

no food was grateful but from phœnix’ hand.

up the dainty morsel that you were to eat, and held the wine-cup

[211]

to your lips.

i pass my watchings o’er thy helpless years,

many a time have you slobbered your wine in baby

the tender labours, the compliant cares,

helplessness over my shirt; i had infinite trouble with you, but

the gods (i thought) reversed their hard decree,
and phœnix felt a father’s joys in thee:

i knew that heaven had vouchsafed me no offspring of my own, and

thy growing virtues justified my cares,

i made a son of you, achilles, that in my hour of need you might

and promised comfort to my silver hairs.

protect me.

now be thy rage, thy fatal rage, resign’d;

now, therefore, i say battle with your pride and beat

a cruel heart ill suits a manly mind:

it; cherish not your anger for ever; the might and majesty of

the gods (the only great, and only wise)

heaven are more than ours, but even heaven may be appeased; and

are moved by offerings, vows, and sacrifice;

if a man has sinned he prays the gods, and reconciles them to

offending man their high compassion wins,

himself by his piteous cries and by frankincense, with

and daily prayers atone for daily sins.

drink-offerings and the savour of burnt sacrifice.
for prayers

prayers are jove’s daughters, of celestial race,
lame are their feet, and wrinkled is their face;
with humble mien, and with dejected eyes,

are as daughters to great jove; halt, wrinkled, with eyes

constant they follow, where injustice flies.

askance, they follow in the footsteps of sin, who, being fierce

injustice swift, erect, and unconfined,

and fleet of foot, leaves them far behind him, and ever baneful

sweeps the wide earth, and tramples o’er mankind,

to mankind outstrips them even to the ends of the world; but

while prayers, to heal her wrongs, move slow behind.

nevertheless the prayers come hobbling and healing after.

who hears these daughters of almighty jove,

if a
man has pity upon these daughters of jove when they draw near

for him they mediate to the throne above:

him, they will bless him and hear him too when he is praying; but

when man rejects the humble suit they make,

if he deny them and will not listen to them, they go to jove the

the sire revenges for the daughters’ sake;

son of saturn and pray that he may presently fall into sin—to his

from jove commission’d, fierce injustice then
descends to punish unrelenting men.
o let not headlong passion bear the sway

ruing bitterly hereafter.

these reconciling goddesses obey:

therefore, achilles, give these

due honours to the seed of jove belong,

daughters of jove due reverence, and bow before them as all good

due honours calm the fierce, and bend the strong.

men will bow.

were these not paid thee by the terms we bring,

were not the son of atreus offering you gifts and

were rage still harbour’d in the haughty king;

promising others later—if he were still furious and implacable—i

nor greece nor all her fortunes should engage
thy friend to plead against so just a rage.

am not he that would bid you throw off your anger and help the

but since what honour asks the general sends,

achaeans, no matter how great their need; but he is giving much

and sends by those whom most thy heart commends;

now, and more hereafter; he has sent his captains to urge his

the best and noblest of the grecian train;

suit, and has chosen those who of all the argives are most

permit not these to sue, and sue in vain!

acceptable to you; make not then their words and their coming to
be of none effect.

let me (my son) an ancient fact unfold,

your anger has been righteous so far.

a great example drawn from times of old;

we have
heard in song how heroes of old time quarrelled when they were

hear what our fathers were, and what their praise,

roused to fury, but still they could be won by gifts, and fair

who conquer’d their revenge in former days.

words could soothe them.

“where calydon on rocky mountains stands[212]

“i have an old story in my mind—a very old one—but you are all

once fought the ætolian and curetian bands;

friends and i will tell it.
the curetes and the aetolians were
fighting and killing one another round calydon—the aetolians

to guard it those; to conquer, these advance;

defending the city and the curetes trying to destroy it.
for
diana of the golden throne was angry and did them hurt because
oeneus had not offered her his harvest first-fruits.

and mutual deaths were dealt with mutual chance.

the other

the silver cynthia bade contention rise,

gods had all been feasted with hecatombs, but to the daughter of

in vengeance of neglected sacrifice;

great jove alone he had made no sacrifice.

on œneus fields she sent a monstrous boar,

he had forgotten her,
or somehow or other it had escaped him, and this was a grievous
sin.
thereon the archer goddess in her displeasure sent a
prodigious creature against him—a savage wild boar with great

that levell’d harvests, and whole forests tore:

white tusks that did much harm to his orchard lands, uprooting
apple-trees in full bloom and throwing them to the ground.

this beast (when many a chief his tusks had slain)

but
meleager son of oeneus got huntsmen and hounds from many cities
and killed it—for it was so monstrous that not a few were needed,
and many a man did it stretch upon his funeral pyre.
on this the

great meleager stretch’d along the plain,

goddess set the curetes and the aetolians fighting furiously

then, for his spoils, a new debate arose,

about the head and skin of the boar.

the neighbour nations thence commencing foes.

“so long as meleager was in the field things went badly with the

strong as they were, the bold curetes fail’d,

curetes, and for all their numbers they could not hold their

while meleager’s thundering arm prevail’d:

ground under the city walls; but in the course of time meleager

till rage at length inflamed his lofty breast
(for rage invades the wisest and the best).

was angered as even a wise man will sometimes be.

“cursed by althaea, to his wrath he yields,

he was incensed

and in his wife’s embrace forgets the fields.

with his mother althaea, and therefore stayed at home with his

(she from marpessa sprung, divinely fair,

and matchless idas, more than man in war:

he it was who took

home with cleopatra, nursing the anger which he felt by reason of

his mother’s curses.

whose luckless hand his royal uncle slew;

his mother, grieving for the death of her

she beat the ground, and call’d the powers beneath

brother, prayed the gods, and beat the earth with her hands,
calling upon hades and on awful proserpine; she went down upon
her knees and her bosom was wet with tears as she prayed that

on her own son to wreak her brother’s death;

they would kill her son—and erinys that walks in darkness and

hell heard her curses from the realms profound,

knows no ruth heard her from erebus.

and the red fiends that walk the nightly round.
in vain ætolia her deliverer waits,

“then was heard the din of battle about the gates of calydon, and

war shakes her walls, and thunders at her gates.

the dull thump of the battering against their walls.

she sent ambassadors, a chosen band,

thereon the

priests of the gods, and elders of the land;
besought the chief to save the sinking state:

elders of the aetolians besought meleager; they sent the chiefest

their prayers were urgent, and their proffers great:

of their priests, and begged him to come out and help them,
promising him a great reward.

(full fifty acres of the richest ground,

they bade him choose fifty
plough-gates, the most fertile in the plain of calydon, the

half pasture green, and half with vineyards crown’d:)

one-half vineyard and the other open plough-land.

his suppliant father, aged œneus, came;

the old warrior
oeneus implored him, standing at the threshold of his room and
beating the doors in supplication.

his sisters follow’d; even the vengeful dame,

his sisters and his mother

althaea, sues; his friends before him fall:

herself besought him sore, but he the more refused them; those of

he stands relentless, and rejects them all.

his comrades who were nearest and dearest to him also prayed him,

meanwhile the victor’s shouts ascend the skies;

but they could not move him till the foe was battering at the

the walls are scaled; the rolling flames arise;

very doors of his chamber, and the curetes had scaled the walls
and were setting fire to the city.

at length his wife (a form divine) appears,

then at last his sorrowing

with piercing cries, and supplicating tears;

wife detailed the horrors that befall those whose city is taken;

she paints the horrors of a conquer’d town,

she reminded him how the men are slain, and the city is given

the heroes slain, the palaces o’erthrown,

over to the flames, while the women and children are carried into

the matrons ravish’d, the whole race enslaved:

captivity; when he heard all this, his heart was touched, and he

the warrior heard, he vanquish’d, and he saved.

donned his armour to go forth.

the ætolians, long disdain’d, now took their turn,

thus of his own inward motion he
saved the city of the aetolians; but they now gave him nothing of
those rich rewards that they had offered earlier, and though he

and left the chief their broken faith to mourn.

saved the city he took nothing by it.

learn hence, betimes to curb pernicious ire,

be not then, my son, thus
minded; let not heaven lure you into any such course.
when the

nor stay till yonder fleets ascend in fire;

ships are burning it will be a harder matter to save them.

accept the presents; draw thy conquering sword;

take
the gifts, and go, for the achaeans will then honour you as a
god; whereas if you fight without taking them, you may beat the

and be amongst our guardian gods adored.

battle back, but you will not be held in like honour.

”

”

thus he: the stern achilles thus replied:
“my second father, and my reverend guide:
thy friend, believe me, no such gifts demands,

and achilles answered, “phoenix, old friend and father, i have no

and asks no honours from a mortal’s hands;

need of such honour.

jove honours me, and favours my designs;
his pleasure guides me, and his will confines;
and here i stay (if such his high behest)

i have honour from jove himself, which will

while life’s warm spirit beats within my breast.

abide with me at my ships while i have breath in my body, and my
limbs are strong.

yet hear one word, and lodge it in thy heart:

i say further—and lay my saying to your

no more molest me on atrides’ part:

heart—vex me no more with this weeping and lamentation, all in

is it for him these tears are taught to flow,

the cause of the son of atreus.

for him these sorrows?

love him so well, and you may

for my mortal foe?
a generous friendship no cold medium knows,
burns with one love, with one resentment glows;

lose the love i bear you.

one should our interests and our passions be;

you ought to help me rather in

my friend must hate the man that injures me.

troubling those that trouble me; be king as much as i am, and

do this, my phœnix, ’tis a generous part;
and share my realms, my honours, and my heart.

share like honour with myself; the others shall take my answer;

let these return: our voyage, or our stay,

stay here yourself and sleep comfortably in your bed; at daybreak

rest undetermined till the dawning day.

we will consider whether to remain or go.

”

”

he ceased; then order’d for the sage’s bed

prepare a bed for phoenix, and that the others should take their

a warmer couch with numerous carpets spread.

leave.

with that, stern ajax his long silence broke,

“hence let us go—why waste we time in vain?
see what effect our low submissions gain!

laertes, let us be gone, for i see that our journey is vain.

liked or not liked, his words we must relate,

we
must now take our answer, unwelcome though it be, to the danaans

proud as he is, that iron heart retains

its stubborn purpose, and his friends disdains.

remorseless; he is cruel, and cares nothing for the love his
comrades lavished upon him more than on all the others.

stern and unpitying!

he is

if a brother bleed,

implacable—and yet if a man’s brother or son has been slain he

on just atonement, we remit the deed;
a sire the slaughter of his son forgives;
the price of blood discharged, the murderer lives:

will accept a fine by way of amends from him that killed him, and

the haughtiest hearts at length their rage resign,
and gifts can conquer every soul but thine.
[213]

the wrong-doer having paid in full remains in peace among his own

the gods that unrelenting breast have steel’d,

and cursed thee with a mind that cannot yield.
one woman-slave was ravish’d from thy arms:

”

“o soul of battles, and thy people’s guide!
(to ajax thus the first of greeks replied)
well hast thou spoke; but at the tyrant’s name

“ajax,” replied achilles, “noble son of telamon, you have spoken

my rage rekindles, and my soul’s on flame:

much to my liking, but my blood boils when i think it all over,

’tis just resentment, and becomes the brave:

and remember how the son of atreus treated me with contumely as

disgraced, dishonour’d, like the vilest slave!

though i were some vile tramp, and that too in the presence of

return, then, heroes!

the argives.

and our answer bear,

go, then, and deliver your message; say that i will

the glorious combat is no more my care;
not till, amidst yon sinking navy slain,

have no concern with fighting till hector, son of noble priam,

the blood of greeks shall dye the sable main;

reaches the tents of the myrmidons in his murderous course, and

not till the flames, by hector’s fury thrown,
consume your vessels, and approach my own;

flings fire upon their ships.

just there, the impetuous homicide shall stand,

for all his lust of battle, i take

there cease his battle, and there feel our hand.

it he will be held in check when he is at my own tent and ship.

”

”

returns the chief, or must our navy fall?

”

“great king of nations!

(ithacus replied)

agamemnon, achilles will not be calmed, but is more fiercely

fix’d is his wrath, unconquer’d is his pride;

angry than ever, and spurns both you and your gifts.

he slights thy friendship, thy proposals scorns,

he bids you

and, thus implored, with fiercer fury burns.
to save our army, and our fleets to free,
is not his care; but left to greece and thee.

take counsel with the achaeans to save the ships and host as you

your eyes shall view, when morning paints the sky,

best may; as for himself, he said that at daybreak he should draw

beneath his oars the whitening billows fly;

his ships into the water.

us too he bids our oars and sails employ,

he said further that he should advise
every one to sail home likewise, for that you will not reach the

nor hope the fall of heaven-protected troy;

goal of ilius.

inspires her war, and bids her glory shine.

to protect it, and the people have taken heart.

ulysses ceased: the great achaian host,

tydides broke

“why should we gifts to proud achilles send,

or strive with prayers his haughty soul to bend?

son of peleus nor offered him gifts.

his country’s woes he glories to deride,

he is proud enough as it is,

and prayers will burst that swelling heart with pride.

and you have encouraged him in his pride still further.

be the fierce impulse of his rage obey’d,

let him

our battles let him or desert or aid;

stay or go as he will.

then let him arm when jove or he think fit:

he will fight later when he is in the

that, to his madness, or to heaven commit:

humour, and heaven puts it in his mind to do so.
now, therefore,

what for ourselves we can, is always ours;

let us all do as i say; we have eaten and drunk our fill, let us

this night, let due repast refresh our powers;
(for strength consists in spirits and in blood,
and those are owed to generous wine and food;)

then take our rest, for in rest there is both strength and stay.

but when the rosy messenger of day

but when fair rosy-fingered morn appears, forthwith bring out

strikes the blue mountains with her golden ray,
ranged at the ships, let all our squadrons shine
in flaming arms, a long-extended line:
in the dread front let great atrides stand,

your host and your horsemen in front of the ships, urging them

the first in danger, as in high command.

on, and yourself fighting among the foremost.

”

”

shouts of acclaim the listening heroes raise,

thus he spoke, and the other chieftains approved his words.

then each to heaven the due libations pays;

they
then made their drink-offerings and went every man to his own

the grateful blessings of desired repose.

tent, where they laid down to rest and enjoyed the boon of sleep.

[214]
[illustration: ] achilles
book x.
argument.

book x.

the night-adventure of diomed and ulysses.
upon the refusal of achilles to return to the army, the distress of
agamemnon is described in the most lively manner.
he takes no rest that
night, but passes through the camp, awaking the leaders, and contriving
all possible methods for the public safety.
menelaus, nestor, ulysses,
and diomed are employed in raising the rest of the captains.
they call
a council of war, and determine to send scouts into the enemies’ camp,
to learn their posture, and discover their intentions.
diomed
undertakes this hazardous enterprise, and makes choice of ulysses for
his companion.
in their passage they surprise dolon, whom hector had
sent on a like design to the camp of the grecians.
from him they are
informed of the situation of the trojan and auxiliary forces, and
particularly of rhesus, and the thracians who were lately arrived.

ulysses and diomed go out as spies, and meet dolon, who gives

they
pass on with success; kill rhesus, with several of his officers, and

them information: they then kill him, and profiting by what he

seize the famous horses of that prince, with which they return in

had told them, kill rhesus king of the thracians and take his

triumph to the camp.

horses.

the same night continues; the scene lies in the two camps.
all night the chiefs before their vessels lay,
and lost in sleep the labours of the day:

now the other princes of the achaeans slept soundly the whole

all but the king: with various thoughts oppress’d,[215]

night through, but agamemnon son of atreus was troubled, so that

his country’s cares lay rolling in his breast.

he could get no rest.

as when by lightnings jove’s ethereal power

as when fair juno’s lord flashes his

foretels the rattling hail, or weighty shower,

lightning in token of great rain or hail or snow when the

or sends soft snows to whiten all the shore,

snow-flakes whiten the ground, or again as a sign that he will

or bids the brazen throat of war to roar;
by fits one flash succeeds as one expires,

open the wide jaws of hungry war, even so did agamemnon heave

and heaven flames thick with momentary fires:
so bursting frequent from atrides’ breast,
sighs following sighs his inward fears confess’d.

many a heavy sigh, for his soul trembled within him.

now o’er the fields, dejected, he surveys

when he

from thousand trojan fires the mounting blaze;

looked upon the plain of troy he marvelled at the many watchfires

hears in the passing wind their music blow,
and marks distinct the voices of the foe.

burning in front of ilius, and at the sound of pipes and flutes

now looking backwards to the fleet and coast,

and of the hum of men, but when presently he turned towards the

anxious he sorrows for the endangered host.
he rends his hair, in sacrifice to jove,

ships and hosts of the achaeans, he tore his hair by handfuls

and sues to him that ever lives above:
inly he groans; while glory and despair

before jove on high, and groaned aloud for the very disquietness

divide his heart, and wage a double war.

of his soul.

a thousand cares his labouring breast revolves;
to seek sage nestor now the chief resolves,

in the end he deemed it best to go at once to nestor

with him, in wholesome counsels, to debate

son of neleus, and see if between them they could find any way of

what yet remains to save the afflicted state.

the achaeans from destruction.

he rose, and first he cast his mantle round,

a lion’s yellow spoils his back conceal’d;

a huge tawny lion over his shoulders—a skin that reached his

his warlike hand a pointed javelin held.

feet—and took his spear in his hand.

meanwhile his brother, press’d with equal woes,

laments for greece, that in his cause before

then he went to rouse his brother,

who was by far the most powerful of the achaeans, and was

honoured by the people as though he were a god.
he found him by

joyful they met; the spartan thus begun:

shoulders, and right glad was he that his brother had come.
menelaus spoke first.

“why puts my brother his bright armour on?

“why,” said he, “my dear brother, are you
thus arming?

sends he some spy, amidst these silent hours,

are you going to send any of our comrades to exploit

to try yon camp, and watch the trojan powers?

the trojans?

but say, what hero shall sustain that task?
such bold exploits uncommon courage ask;

i greatly fear that no one will do you this service,

guideless, alone, through night’s dark shade to go,
and midst a hostile camp explore the foe.

and spy upon the enemy alone in the dead of night.

”

it will be a
deed of great daring.
”

to whom the king: “in such distress we stand,

and king agamemnon answered, “menelaus, we both of us need shrewd

no vulgar counsel our affairs demand;

counsel to save the argives and our ships, for jove has changed

greece to preserve, is now no easy part,
but asks high wisdom, deep design, and art.
for jove, averse, our humble prayer denies,
and bows his head to hector’s sacrifice.

his mind, and inclines towards hector’s sacrifices rather than

what eye has witness’d, or what ear believed,

ours.
i never saw nor heard tell of any man as having wrought

in one great day, by one great arm achieved,
such wondrous deeds as hector’s hand has done,
and we beheld, the last revolving sun?

such ruin in one day as hector has now wrought against the sons

what honours the beloved of jove adorn!

of the achaeans—and that too of his own unaided self, for he is

sprung from no god, and of no goddess born;

son neither to god nor goddess.

yet such his acts, as greeks unborn shall tell,

the argives will rue it long and

and curse the battle where their fathers fell.

deeply.

“now speed thy hasty course along the fleet,

run, therefore, with all speed by the line of the ships,

there call great ajax, and the prince of crete;

and call ajax and idomeneus.

ourself to hoary nestor will repair;

meanwhile i will go to nestor, and
bid him rise and go about among the companies of our sentinels to

to keep the guards on duty be his care,

give them their instructions; they will listen to him sooner than
to any man, for his own son, and meriones brother in arms to
idomeneus, are captains over them.

(for nestor’s influence best that quarter guides,

it was to them more

whose son with merion, o’er the watch presides.

particularly that we gave this charge.

”)

”

to whom the spartan: “these thy orders borne,

menelaus replied, “how do i take your meaning?

say, shall i stay, or with despatch return?

am i to stay with
them and wait your coming, or shall i return here as soon as i

”

have given your orders?

“there shall thou stay, (the king of men replied,)

” “wait,” answered king agamemnon, “for

else may we miss to meet, without a guide,

there are so many paths about the camp that we might miss one

the paths so many, and the camp so wide.

another.

still, with your voice the slothful soldiers raise,

call every man on your way, and bid him be stirring;

urge by their fathers’ fame their future praise.

name him by his lineage and by his father’s name, give each all

forget we now our state and lofty birth;

titular observance, and stand not too much upon your own dignity;

not titles here, but works, must prove our worth.

we must take our full share of toil, for at our birth jove laid

to labour is the lot of man below;
and when jove gave us life, he gave us woe.

this heavy burden upon us.

”

”

this said, each parted to his several cares:

with these instructions he sent his brother on his way, and went

the king to nestor’s sable ship repairs;

on to nestor shepherd of his people.

the sage protector of the greeks he found

he found him sleeping in his

stretch’d in his bed with all his arms around;

tent hard by his own ship; his goodly armour lay beside him—his

the various-colour’d scarf, the shield he rears,
the shining helmet, and the pointed spears;

shield, his two spears and his helmet; beside him also lay the

the dreadful weapons of the warrior’s rage,

gleaming girdle with which the old man girded himself when he

that, old in arms, disdain’d the peace of age.

armed to lead his people into battle—for his age stayed him not.

then, leaning on his hand his watchful head,
the hoary monarch raised his eyes and said:

he raised himself on his elbow and looked up at agamemnon.

“what art thou, speak, that on designs unknown,

“who
is it,” said he, “that goes thus about the host and the ships

while others sleep, thus range the camp alone;

alone and in the dead of night, when men are sleeping?

seek’st thou some friend or nightly sentinel?

are you
looking for one of your mules or for some comrade?

stand off, approach not, but thy purpose tell.

do not stand
there and say nothing, but speak.

”

what is your business?
”

“o son of neleus, (thus the king rejoin’d,)
pride of the greeks, and glory of thy kind!

and agamemnon answered, “nestor, son of neleus, honour to the

lo, here the wretched agamemnon stands,
the unhappy general of the grecian bands,
whom jove decrees with daily cares to bend,

achaean name, it is i, agamemnon son of atreus, on whom jove has

and woes, that only with his life shall end!

laid labour and sorrow so long as there is breath in my body and

scarce can my knees these trembling limbs sustain,
and scarce my heart support its load of pain.

my limbs carry me.

no taste of sleep these heavy eyes have known,

i am thus abroad because sleep sits not upon

confused, and sad, i wander thus alone,

my eyelids, but my heart is big with war and with the jeopardy of

with fears distracted, with no fix’d design;

the achaeans.

and all my people’s miseries are mine.

i am in great fear for the danaans.

if aught of use thy waking thoughts suggest,

i am at sea,

(since cares, like mine, deprive thy soul of rest,)

and without sure counsel; my heart beats as though it would leap

impart thy counsel, and assist thy friend;

out of my body, and my limbs fail me.

now let us jointly to the trench descend,

if then you can do

at every gate the fainting guard excite,

anything—for you too cannot sleep—let us go the round of the

tired with the toils of day and watch of night;

watch, and see whether they are drowsy with toil and sleeping to
the neglect of their duty.

else may the sudden foe our works invade,

the enemy is encamped hard and we know

so near, and favour’d by the gloomy shade.

not but he may attack us by night.

”

”

to him thus nestor: “trust the powers above,

nestor replied, “most noble son of atreus, king of men,

nor think proud hector’s hopes confirm’d by jove:
how ill agree the views of vain mankind,

agamemnon, jove will not do all for hector that hector thinks he

and the wise counsels of the eternal mind!
audacious hector, if the gods ordain
that great achilles rise and rage again,
what toils attend thee, and what woes remain!

will; he will have troubles yet in plenty if achilles will lay

lo, faithful nestor thy command obeys;

aside his anger.

the care is next our other chiefs to raise:

i will go with you, and we will rouse others,

ulysses, diomed, we chiefly need;

either the son of tydeus, or ulysses, or fleet ajax and the

meges for strength, oïleus famed for speed.

valiant son of phyleus.

some other be despatch’d of nimbler feet,

some one had also better go and call ajax

to those tall ships, remotest of the fleet,
where lie great ajax and the king of crete.

and king idomeneus, for their ships are not near at hand but the

[216]

farthest of all.

to rouse the spartan i myself decree;

i cannot however refrain from blaming menelaus,

dear as he is to us, and dear to thee,

much as i love him and respect him—and i will say so plainly,

yet must i tax his sloth, that claims no share

even at the risk of offending you—for sleeping and leaving all

with his great brother in his martial care:

this trouble to yourself.

him it behoved to every chief to sue,

he ought to be going about imploring

preventing every part perform’d by you;
for strong necessity our toils demands,
claims all our hearts, and urges all our hands.

aid from all the princes of the achaeans, for we are in extreme

”

danger.
”

to whom the king: “with reverence we allow

and agamemnon answered, “sir, you may sometimes blame him justly,

thy just rebukes, yet learn to spare them now:

for he is often remiss and unwilling to exert himself—not indeed

my generous brother is of gentle kind,
he seems remiss, but bears a valiant mind;
through too much deference to our sovereign sway,

from sloth, nor yet heedlessness, but because he looks to me and

content to follow when we lead the way:

expects me to take the lead.

but now, our ills industrious to prevent,

on this occasion, however, he was

long ere the rest he rose, and sought my tent.

awake before i was, and came to me of his own accord.
i have

the chiefs you named, already at his call,

already sent him to call the very men whom you have named.

prepare to meet us near the navy-wall;

and
now let us be going.
we shall find them with the watch outside

assembling there, between the trench and gates,
near the night-guards, our chosen council waits.

the gates, for it was there i said that we would meet them.

”

”

“then none (said nestor) shall his rule withstand,

“in that case,” answered nestor, “the argives will not blame him
nor disobey his orders when he urges them to fight or gives them

for great examples justify command.

instructions.

”

with that, the venerable warrior rose;

with this he put on his shirt, and bound his sandals about his

the shining greaves his manly legs enclose;

comely feet.

his purple mantle golden buckles join’d,

“o prudent chief!

nestor knight of gerene answered, “ulysses, noble son of laertes,

wise as thou art, be now thy wisdom tried:

take it not amiss, for the achaeans are in great straits.

whatever means of safety can be sought,

come

whatever counsels can inspire our thought,

with me and let us wake some other, who may advise well with us

whatever methods, or to fly or fight;
all, all depend on this important night!

whether we shall fight or fly.

”

”

he heard, return’d, and took his painted shield;

then join’d the chiefs, and follow’d through the field.

his shoulders and came out with them.

without his tent, bold diomed they found,

first they went to diomed
son of tydeus, and found him outside his tent clad in his armour

all sheathed in arms, his brave companions round:
each sunk in sleep, extended on the field,
his head reclining on his bossy shield.

with his comrades sleeping round him and using their shields as

a wood of spears stood by, that, fix’d upright,

pillows; as for their spears, they stood upright on the spikes of
their butts that were driven into the ground, and the burnished

shot from their flashing points a quivering light.

bronze flashed afar like the lightning of father jove.

a bull’s black hide composed the hero’s bed;

the hero

a splendid carpet roll’d beneath his head.

was sleeping upon the skin of an ox, with a piece of fine carpet
under his head; nestor went up to him and stirred him with his

himself.

“rise, son of tydeus!

“wake up,” he exclaimed, “son of tydeus.

to the brave and strong

how can you

rest seems inglorious, and the night too long.

sleep on in this way?

but sleep’st thou now, when from yon hill the foe

can you not see that the trojans are

hangs o’er the fleet, and shades our walls below?

encamped on the brow of the plain hard by our ships, with but a
little space between us and them?

”

”

at this, soft slumber from his eyelids fled;
the warrior saw the hoary chief, and said:
“wondrous old man!

on these words diomed leaped up instantly and said, “old man,

whose soul no respite knows,

your heart is of iron; you rest not one moment from your labours.

though years and honours bid thee seek repose,

are there no younger men among the achaeans who could go about to

let younger greeks our sleeping warriors wake;

rouse the princes?

ill fits thy age these toils to undertake.

there is no tiring you.

”

”

“my friend, (he answered,) generous is thy care;

and nestor knight of gerene made answer, “my son, all that you
have said is true.

these toils, my subjects and my sons might bear;

i have good sons, and also much people who

their loyal thoughts and pious love conspire
to ease a sovereign and relieve a sire:
but now the last despair surrounds our host;

might call the chieftains, but the achaeans are in the gravest

no hour must pass, no moment must be lost;
each single greek, in this conclusive strife,

danger; life and death are balanced as it were on the edge of a

stands on the sharpest edge of death or life:

razor.

yet, if my years thy kind regard engage,
employ thy youth as i employ my age;
succeed to these my cares, and rouse the rest;

go then, for you are younger than i, and of your courtesy

he serves me most, who serves his country best.

rouse ajax and the fleet son of phyleus.

”

”

and now the chiefs approach the nightly guard;
a wakeful squadron, each in arms prepared:
the unwearied watch their listening leaders keep,

the round of those who were on guard, and found the captains not

and, couching close, repel invading sleep.
so faithful dogs their fleecy charge maintain,

sleeping at their posts but wakeful and sitting with their arms

with toil protected from the prowling train;

about them.

when the gaunt lioness, with hunger bold,

as sheep dogs that watch their flocks when they are

springs from the mountains toward the guarded fold:
through breaking woods her rustling course they hear;
loud, and more loud, the clamours strike their ear

yarded, and hear a wild beast coming through the mountain forest

of hounds and men: they start, they gaze around,

towards them—forthwith there is a hue and cry of dogs and men,

watch every side, and turn to every sound.

and slumber is broken—even so was sleep chased from the eyes of

thus watch’d the grecians, cautious of surprise,

the achaeans as they kept the watches of the wicked night, for

each voice, each motion, drew their ears and eyes:
each step of passing feet increased the affright;

they turned constantly towards the plain whenever they heard any

and hostile troy was ever full in sight.

stir among the trojans.

nestor with joy the wakeful band survey’d,

your nightly cares employ;

they sat down, therefore,

the council opening, in these words begun:

and held debate with one another.
nestor spoke first.

“is there (said he) a chief so greatly brave,
his life to hazard, and his country save?
lives there a man, who singly dares to go

“my friends,” said he, “is there any man bold

to yonder camp, or seize some straggling foe?

enough to venture among the trojans, and cut off some straggler,

or favour’d by the night approach so near,
their speech, their counsels, and designs to hear?

or bring us news of what the enemy mean to do whether they will

if to besiege our navies they prepare,

stay here by the ships away from the city, or whether, now that
they have worsted the achaeans, they will retire within their

or troy once more must be the seat of war?

walls.

this could he learn, and to our peers recite,
and pass unharm’d the dangers of the night;

if he could learn all this and come back safely here, his

what fame were his through all succeeding days,
while phœbus shines, or men have tongues to praise!

fame would be high as heaven in the mouths of all men, and he

what gifts his grateful country would bestow!
what must not greece to her deliverer owe?
a sable ewe each leader should provide,

would be rewarded richly; for the chiefs from all our ships would

with each a sable lambkin by her side;

each of them give him a black ewe with her lamb—which is a

at every rite his share should be increased,

present of surpassing value—and he would be asked as a guest to

and his the foremost honours of the feast.

all feasts and clan-gatherings.

”

”

fear held them mute: alone, untaught to fear,

they all held their peace, but diomed of the loud war-cry spoke

through yon black camps to bend my dangerous way,

against us, but if another will go with me i shall do so in

to raise my hopes, and second my design.

greater confidence and comfort.

by mutual confidence and mutual aid,

when two men are together, one of

great deeds are done, and great discoveries made;

them may see some opportunity which the other has not caught

the wise new prudence from the wise acquire,

sight of; if a man is alone he is less full of resource, and his

and one brave hero fans another’s fire.

wit is weaker.

”

contending leaders at the word arose;

the two ajaxes,

undaunted diomed!
what chief to join

would now go with you.

in this great enterprise, is only thine.
just be thy choice, without affection made;

do not through delicacy reject the better

to birth, or office, no respect be paid;
let worth determine here.

” the monarch spake,

he is of more royal blood.
”

and inly trembled for his brother’s sake.

diomed answered, “if

my choice declares the impulse of my mind.

you bid me take the man of my own choice, how in that case can i

to lend his counsels and assist our hands?
a chief, whose safety is minerva’s care;

face all kinds of danger—and pallas minerva loves him well?

so famed, so dreadful, in the works of war:

if he

bless’d in his conduct, i no aid require;

were to go with me we should pass safely through fire itself, for

wisdom like his might pass through flames of fire.

he is quick to see and understand.

”

”

“it fits thee not, before these chiefs of fame,
(replied the sage,) to praise me, or to blame:

“son of tydeus,” replied ulysses, “say neither good nor ill about

praise from a friend, or censure from a foe,
are lost on hearers that our merits know.

me, for you are among argives who know me well.

but let us haste—night rolls the hours away,

let us be going,

the reddening orient shows the coming day,

for the night wanes and dawn is at hand.

the stars shine fainter on the ethereal plains,

the stars have gone

and of night’s empire but a third remains.

forward, two-thirds of the night are already spent, and the third
is alone left us.

”

”

thus having spoke, with generous ardour press’d,
in arms terrific their huge limbs they dress’d.

they then put on their armour.

a two-edged falchion thrasymed the brave,

brave thrasymedes provided the son

and ample buckler, to tydides gave:

either peak or crest; it is called a skull-cap and is a common

(such as by youths unused to arms are worn:)

headgear.

no spoils enrich it, and no studs adorn.

of ulysses.

great deeds of daring, for you were his ready helper.

so now be present, o celestial maid!

even so

so still continue to the race thine aid!

guide me and guard me now, and in return i will offer you in

a youthful steer shall fall beneath the stroke,

sacrifice a broad-browed heifer of a year old, unbroken, and

untamed, unconscious of the galling yoke,

never yet brought by man under the yoke.

with ample forehead, and with spreading horns,

i will gild her horns

whose taper tops refulgent gold adorns.

and will offer her up to you in sacrifice.

”

”

the heroes pray’d, and pallas from the skies

thus they prayed, and pallas minerva heard their prayer.
when

accords their vow, succeeds their enterprise.

they had done praying to the daughter of great jove, they went

now, like two lions panting for the prey,
with dreadful thoughts they trace the dreary way,

their way like two lions prowling by night amid the armour and

through the black horrors of the ensanguined plain,
through dust, through blood, o’er arms, and hills of slain.

blood-stained bodies of them that had fallen.

nor less bold hector, and the sons of troy,
on high designs the wakeful hours employ;

neither again did hector let the trojans sleep; for he too called

the assembled peers their lofty chief enclosed;

the princes and councillors of the trojans that he might set his

who thus the counsels of his breast proposed:

counsel before them.

“what glorious man, for high attempts prepared,

“is there one,” said he, “who for a great

dares greatly venture for a rich reward?
of yonder fleet a bold discovery make,
what watch they keep, and what resolves they take?

reward will do me the service of which i will tell you?

if now subdued they meditate their flight,

he shall

and, spent with toil, neglect the watch of night?

be well paid if he will.

his be the chariot that shall please him most,

i will give him a chariot and a couple
of horses, the fleetest that can be found at the ships of the
achaeans, if he will dare this thing; and he will win infinite
honour to boot; he must go to the ships and find out whether they

of all the plunder of the vanquish’d host;

are still guarded as heretofore, or whether now that we have

his the fair steeds that all the rest excel,

beaten them the achaeans design to fly, and through sheer

and his the glory to have served so well.

exhaustion are neglecting to keep their watches.

”

”

a youth there was among the tribes of troy,

they all held their peace; but there was among the trojans a

dolon his name, eumedes’ only boy,
(five girls beside the reverend herald told.

certain man named dolon, son of eumedes, the famous herald—a man

)
rich was the son in brass, and rich in gold;

rich in gold and bronze.

not bless’d by nature with the charms of face,

he was ill-favoured, but a good runner,

but swift of foot, and matchless in the race.

and was an only son among five sisters.

“hector!

he it was that now
addressed the trojans.

(he said) my courage bids me meet

“i, hector,” said he, “will to the ships

this high achievement, and explore the fleet:

and will exploit them.

but first exalt thy sceptre to the skies,

but first hold up your sceptre and swear

and swear to grant me the demanded prize;
the immortal coursers, and the glittering car,

that you will give me the chariot, bedight with bronze, and the

that bear pelides through the ranks of war.

horses that now carry the noble son of peleus.

encouraged thus, no idle scout i go,

i will make you a

fulfil thy wish, their whole intention know,

good scout, and will not fail you.

even to the royal tent pursue my way,

i will go through the host
from one end to the other till i come to the ship of agamemnon,
where i take it the princes of the achaeans are now consulting

and all their counsels, all their aims betray.

whether they shall fight or fly.

”

”

the chief then heaved the golden sceptre high,

when he had done speaking hector held up his sceptre, and swore

attesting thus the monarch of the sky:

him his oath saying, “may jove the thundering husband of juno

“be witness thou!
immortal lord of all!
whose thunder shakes the dark aerial hall:
by none but dolon shall this prize be borne,

bear witness that no other trojan but yourself shall mount those

and him alone the immortal steeds adorn.

steeds, and that you shall have your will with them for ever.

”

”

thus hector swore: the gods were call’d in vain,

the oath he swore was bootless, but it made dolon more keen on

but the rash youth prepares to scour the plain:

going.

across his back the bended bow he flung,

he hung his bow over his shoulder, and as an overall he

a wolf’s grey hide around his shoulders hung,

wore the skin of a grey wolf, while on his head he set a cap of

a ferret’s downy fur his helmet lined,

ferret skin.

and in his hand a pointed javelin shined.

then he took a pointed javelin, and left the camp

then (never to return) he sought the shore,

for the ships, but he was not to return with any news for hector.

and trod the path his feet must tread no more.

when he had left the horses and the troops behind him, he made

scarce had he pass’d the steeds and trojan throng,
(still bending forward as he coursed along,)
when, on the hollow way, the approaching tread

all speed on his way, but ulysses perceived his coming and said

ulysses mark’d, and thus to diomed;
“o friend!
i hear some step of hostile feet,

to diomed, “diomed, here is some one from the camp; i am not sure

moving this way, or hastening to the fleet;
some spy, perhaps, to lurk beside the main;
or nightly pillager that strips the slain.

whether he is a spy, or whether it is some thief who would

yet let him pass, and win a little space;

plunder the bodies of the dead; let him get a little past us, we

then rush behind him, and prevent his pace.

can then spring upon him and take him.

but if too swift of foot he flies before,

if, however, he is too

confine his course along the fleet and shore,
betwixt the camp and him our spears employ,

quick for us, go after him with your spear and hem him in towards

and intercept his hoped return to troy.

the ships away from the trojan camp, to prevent his getting back

”

to the town.
”

with that they stepp’d aside, and stoop’d their head,

with this they turned out of their way and lay down among the

(as dolon pass’d,) behind a heap of dead:

corpses.

along the path the spy unwary flew;

dolon suspected nothing and soon passed them, but when

soft, at just distance, both the chiefs pursue.
so distant they, and such the space between,

he had got about as far as the distance by which a mule-plowed

as when two teams of mules divide the green,
(to whom the hind like shares of land allows,)

furrow exceeds one that has been ploughed by oxen (for mules can

when now new furrows part the approaching ploughs.

plow fallow land quicker than oxen) they ran after him, and when

now dolon, listening, heard them as they pass’d;

he heard their footsteps he stood still, for he made sure they

hector (he thought) had sent, and check’d his haste,

were friends from the trojan camp come by hector’s orders to bid

till scarce at distance of a javelin’s throw,

him return; when, however, they were only a spear’s cast, or
less, away from him, he saw that they were enemies and ran as

no voice succeeding, he perceived the foe.

fast as his legs could take him.

as when two skilful hounds the leveret wind;

the others gave chase at once,
and as a couple of well-trained hounds press forward after a doe

or chase through woods obscure the trembling hind;

or hare that runs screaming in front of them, even so did the son

now lost, now seen, they intercept his way,
and from the herd still turn the flying prey:

of tydeus and ulysses pursue dolon and cut him off from his own

so fast, and with such fears, the trojan flew;

people.

so close, so constant, the bold greeks pursue.

but when he had fled so far towards the ships that he

now almost on the fleet the dastard falls,
and mingles with the guards that watch the walls;

would soon have fallen in with the outposts, minerva infused

when brave tydides stopp’d; a gen’rous thought

fresh strength into the son of tydeus for fear some other of the

(inspired by pallas) in his bosom wrought,

achaeans might have the glory of being first to hit him, and he

lest on the foe some forward greek advance,

might himself be only second; he therefore sprang forward with

and snatch the glory from his lifted lance.
then thus aloud: “whoe’er thou art, remain;

his spear and said, “stand, or i shall throw my spear, and in

this javelin else shall fix thee to the plain.

that case i shall soon make an end of you.

”

”

he said, and high in air the weapon cast,

he threw as he spoke, but missed his aim on purpose.

which wilful err’d, and o’er his shoulder pass’d;

the dart

then fix’d in earth.

flew over the man’s right shoulder, and then stuck in the ground.

against the trembling wood
the wretch stood propp’d, and quiver’d as he stood;

he stood stock still, trembling and in great fear; his teeth

a sudden palsy seized his turning head;
his loose teeth chatter’d, and his colour fled;

chattered, and he turned pale with fear.

the panting warriors seize him as he stands,

the two came breathless

and with unmanly tears his life demands.

up to him and seized his hands, whereon he began to weep and

“o spare my youth, and for the breath i owe,

said, “take me alive; i will ransom myself; we have great store

large gifts of price my father shall bestow:

of gold, bronze, and wrought iron, and from this my father will

vast heaps of brass shall in your ships be told,

satisfy you with a very large ransom, should he hear of my being

and steel well-temper’d and refulgent gold.

alive at the ships of the achaeans.

”

”

to whom ulysses made this wise reply:
“whoe’er thou art, be bold, nor fear to die.

“fear not,” replied ulysses, “let no thought of death be in your

what moves thee, say, when sleep has closed the sight,

mind; but tell me, and tell me true, why are you thus going about

to roam the silent fields in dead of night?

alone in the dead of night away from your camp and towards the
ships, while other men are sleeping?

cam’st thou the secrets of our camp to find,

is it to plunder the bodies

by hector prompted, or thy daring mind?
or art some wretch by hopes of plunder led,

of the slain, or did hector send you to spy out what was going on

through heaps of carnage, to despoil the dead?

at the ships?
or did you come here of your own mere notion?

”

”

then thus pale dolon, with a fearful look:
(still, as he spoke, his limbs with horror shook:)
“hither i came, by hector’s words deceived;

dolon answered, his limbs trembling beneath him: “hector, with

much did he promise, rashly i believed:

his vain flattering promises, lured me from my better judgement.

no less a bribe than great achilles’ car,

he said he would give me the horses of the noble son of peleus

and those swift steeds that sweep the ranks of war,
urged me, unwilling, this attempt to make;

and his bronze-bedizened chariot; he bade me go through the

to learn what counsels, what resolves you take:

darkness of the flying night, get close to the enemy, and find

if now subdued, you fix your hopes on flight,

out whether the ships are still guarded as heretofore, or
whether, now that we have beaten them, the achaeans design to
fly, and through sheer exhaustion are neglecting to keep their

and, tired with toils, neglect the watch of night.

watches.

”

“bold was thy aim, and glorious was the prize,

i saw his coursers in proud triumph go,

his
horses are the finest and strongest that i have ever seen, they

swift as the wind, and white as winter-snow;

are whiter than snow and fleeter than any wind that blows.

rich silver plates his shining car infold;

his

his solid arms, refulgent, flame with gold;

chariot is bedight with silver and gold, and he has brought his

no mortal shoulders suit the glorious load,

marvellous golden armour, of the rarest workmanship—too splendid

celestial panoply, to grace a god!

for any mortal man to carry, and meet only for the gods.

let me, unhappy, to your fleet be borne,

now,

or leave me here, a captive’s fate to mourn,

therefore, take me to the ships or bind me securely here, until

in cruel chains, till your return reveal

”

true.

to this tydides, with a gloomy frown:

“think not to live, though all the truth be shown:

all the good information you have given us, that you shall escape

shall we dismiss thee, in some future strife

now you are in our hands, for if we ransom you or let you go, you

or that again our camps thou may’st explore?

will come some second time to the ships of the achaeans either as

no—once a traitor, thou betray’st no more.

a spy or as an open enemy, but if i kill you and an end of you,
you will give no more trouble.

”

”

pallas (this said) her hero’s bosom warms,
breathed in his heart, and strung his nervous arms;
where’er he pass’d, a purple stream pursued
his thirsty falchion, fat with hostile blood,
bathed all his footsteps, dyed the fields with gore,

thereon minerva put courage into the heart of diomed, and he

and a low groan remurmur’d through the shore.

smote them right and left.

so the grim lion, from his nightly den,

were being hacked about, and the earth was red with their blood.

on sheep or goats, resistless in his way,

till twelve lay breathless of the thracian band.

yet used to them.

now twelve despatch’d, the monarch last they found;

killed him too (which made thirteen), as he was breathing hard,

just then a deathful dream minerva sent,
a warlike form appear’d before his tent,
whose visionary steel his bosom tore:
so dream’d the monarch, and awaked no more.

for by the counsel of minerva an evil dream, the seed of oeneus,

from the chariot.

then gave his friend the signal to retire;

but him, new dangers, new achievements fire;

but diomed stayed where he was, thinking what other daring deed

“say thou, whose praises all our host proclaim,
thou living glory of the grecian name!

“tell me,” said he, “renowned ulysses, how did you

say whence these coursers?

two come by these horses?

forces, or did some god meet you and give them to you?

not those fair steeds, so radiant and so gay,

they are

that draw the burning chariot of the day.

like sunbeams.

old as i am, to age i scorn to yield,

i am well conversant with the trojans, for old

and daily mingle in the martial field;
but sure till now no coursers struck my sight

warrior though i am i never hold back by the ships, but i never

like these, conspicuous through the ranks of fight.

yet saw or heard of such horses as these are.

some god, i deem, conferred the glorious prize,

surely some god

bless’d as ye are, and favourites of the skies;

must have met you and given them to you, for you are both of you

the care of him who bids the thunder roar,
and her, whose fury bathes the world with gore.

dear to jove, and to jove’s daughter minerva.

and from their necks and thighs.

then in the polished bath, refresh’d from toil,

when the sea-water had taken all
the sweat from off them, and had refreshed them, they went into
the baths and washed themselves.

their joints they supple with dissolving oil,

after they had so done and had

they sit, rejoicing in her aid divine,

book xi.

minerva.

argument

book xi.

the third battle, and the acts of agamemnon.
agamemnon, having armed himself, leads the grecians to battle; hector

in the forenoon the fight is equal, but agamemnon turns the

prepares the trojans to receive them, while jupiter, juno, and minerva
give the signals of war.

fortune of the day towards the achaeans until he gets wounded and

agamemnon bears all before him and hector is
commanded by jupiter (who sends iris for that purpose) to decline the
engagement, till the king shall be wounded and retire from the field.
he then makes a great slaughter of the enemy.

leaves the field—hector then drives everything before him till he

ulysses and diomed put a
stop to him for a time but the latter, being wounded by paris, is
obliged to desert his companion, who is encompassed by the trojans,
wounded, and in the utmost danger, till menelaus and ajax rescue him.

is wounded by diomed—paris wounds diomed—ulysses, nestor, and

hector comes against ajax, but that hero alone opposes multitudes, and
rallies the greeks.
in the meantime machaon, in the other wing of the
army, is pierced with an arrow by paris, and carried from the fight in

idomeneus perform prodigies of valour—machaon is wounded—nestor

nestor’s chariot.
achilles (who overlooked the action from his ship)

drives him off in his chariot—achilles sees the pair driving

sent patroclus to inquire which of the greeks was wounded in that
manner; nestor entertains him in his tent with an account of the
accidents of the day, and a long recital of some former wars which he
remembered, tending to put patroclus upon persuading achilles to fight
for his countrymen, or at least to permit him to do it, clad in

towards the camp and sends patroclus to ask who it is that is

achilles’ armour.
patroclus, on his return, meets eurypylus also
wounded, and assists him in that distress.
this book opens with the eight-and-twentieth day of the poem, and

wounded—this is the beginning of evil for patroclus—nestor makes

the same day, with its various actions and adventures is extended
through the twelfth, thirteenth, fourteenth, fifteenth, sixteenth,
seventeenth, and part of the eighteenth books.
the scene lies in
the field near the monument of ilus.

a long speech.

the saffron morn, with early blushes spread,[219]
now rose refulgent from tithonus’ bed;

and now as dawn rose from her couch beside tithonus, harbinger of

with new-born day to gladden mortal sight,
and gild the courts of heaven with sacred light:
when baleful eris, sent by jove’s command,

light alike to mortals and immortals, jove sent fierce discord

the torch of discord blazing in her hand,

with the ensign of war in her hands to the ships of the achaeans.

through the red skies her bloody sign extends,
and, wrapt in tempests, o’er the fleet descends.

she took her stand by the huge black hull of ulysses’ ship which

high on ulysses’ bark her horrid stand

was middlemost of all, so that her voice might carry farthest on

either side, on the one hand towards the tents of ajax son of

great hector, cover’d with his spacious shield,
plies all the troops, and orders all the field.

hector’s round shield showed in the front rank, and as some

as the red star now shows his sanguine fires

baneful star that shines for a moment through a rent in the

through the dark clouds, and now in night retires,

clouds and is again hidden beneath them; even so was hector now

thus through the ranks appear’d the godlike man,
plunged in the rear, or blazing in the van;
while streamy sparkles, restless as he flies,

seen in the front ranks and now again in the hindermost, and his

flash from his arms, as lightning from the skies.

bronze armour gleamed like the lightning of aegis-bearing jove.

as sweating reapers in some wealthy field,

and now as a band of reapers mow swathes of wheat or barley upon
a rich man’s land, and the sheaves fall thick before them, even

ranged in two bands, their crooked weapons wield,
bear down the furrows, till their labours meet;
thick fall the heapy harvests at their feet:
so greece and troy the field of war divide,
and falling ranks are strow’d on every side.

so did the trojans and achaeans fall upon one another; they were

none stoop’d a thought to base inglorious flight;[221]
but horse to horse, and man to man they fight,
not rabid wolves more fierce contest their prey;

in no mood for yielding but fought like wolves, and neither side

each wounds, each bleeds, but none resign the day.

got the better of the other.

discord with joy the scene of death descries,

discord was glad as she beheld them,

and drinks large slaughter at her sanguine eyes:

for she was the only god that went among them; the others were

discord alone, of all the immortal train,
swells the red horrors of this direful plain:
the gods in peace their golden mansions fill,

not there, but stayed quietly each in his own home among the

ranged in bright order on the olympian hill:

dells and valleys of olympus.

but general murmurs told their griefs above,

all of them blamed the son of
saturn for wanting to give victory to the trojans, but father

and each accused the partial will of jove.
meanwhile apart, superior, and alone,

jove heeded them not: he held aloof from all, and sat apart in

the eternal monarch, on his awful throne,
wrapt in the blaze of boundless glory sate;
and fix’d, fulfill’d the just decrees of fate.
on earth he turn’d his all-considering eyes,
and mark’d the spot where ilion’s towers arise;

his all-glorious majesty, looking down upon the city of the

the sea with ships, the fields with armies spread,

the victor’s rage, the dying, and the dead.

alike upon the slayers and on the slain.

thus while the morning-beams, increasing bright,

now so long as the day waxed and it was still morning, their

commutual death the fate of war confounds,
each adverse battle gored with equal wounds.

darts rained thick on one another and the people perished, but as

great agamemnon then the slaughter led,

whose squire oïleus, with a sudden spring,

charioteer oileus, who sprang from his chariot and was coming

but in his front he felt the fatal wound,

full towards him; but agamemnon struck him on the forehead with
his spear; his bronze visor was of no avail against the weapon,

which pierced his brain, and stretch’d him on the ground.

which pierced both bronze and bone, so that his brains were
battered in and he was killed in full fight.

atrides spoil’d, and left them on the plain:
vain was their youth, their glittering armour vain:
now soil’d with dust, and naked to the sky,

agamemnon stripped their shirts from off them and left them with

their snowy limbs and beauteous bodies lie.

their breasts all bare to lie where they had fallen.

two sons of priam next to battle move,

”

this said, pisander from the car he cast,

and pierced his breast: supine he breathed his last.

achaeans.

as when the winds with raging flames conspire,
and o’er the forests roll the flood of fire,

as when some mighty forest is all ablaze—the eddying

in blazing heaps the grove’s old honours fall,
and one refulgent ruin levels all:

gusts whirl fire in all directions till the thickets shrivel and

the battle was now in

new force, new spirit, to each breast returns;

array and they stood face to face with one another, agamemnon

the fight renew’d with fiercer fury burns:

ever pressing forward in his eagerness to be ahead of all others.

the king leads on: all fix on him their eye,

tell me now ye muses that dwell in the mansions of olympus, who,

and learn from him to conquer, or to die.

whether of the trojans or of their allies, was first to face

ye sacred nine!
celestial muses!
tell,

agamemnon?

who faced him first, and by his prowess fell?
the great iphidamas, the bold and young,
from sage antenor and theano sprung;

it was iphidamas son of antenor, a man both brave and

whom from his youth his grandsire cisseus bred,

of great stature, who was brought up in fertile thrace, the

and nursed in thrace where snowy flocks are fed.

mother of sheep.

scarce did the down his rosy cheeks invest,
and early honour warm his generous breast,

cisses, his mother’s father, brought him up in

when the kind sire consign’d his daughter’s charms
(theano’s sister) to his youthful arms.
but call’d by glory to the wars of troy,

his own house when he was a child—cisses, father to fair theano.

he leaves untasted the first fruits of joy;

when he reached manhood, cisses would have kept him there, and

from his loved bride departs with melting eyes,
and swift to aid his dearer country flies.

was for giving him his daughter in marriage, but as soon as he

with twelve black ships he reach’d percope’s strand,

had married he set out to fight the achaeans with twelve ships
that followed him: these he had left at percote and had come on

thence took the long laborious march by land.

by land to ilius.

now fierce for fame, before the ranks he springs,

he it was that now met agamemnon son of atreus.

towering in arms, and braves the king of kings.

when they were close up with one another, the son of atreus

atrides first discharged the missive spear;
the trojan stoop’d, the javelin pass’d in air.

missed his aim, and iphidamas hit him on the girdle below the

then near the corslet, at the monarch’s heart,
with all his strength, the youth directs his dart:

cuirass and then flung himself upon him, trusting to his strength

but the broad belt, with plates of silver bound,

of arm; the girdle, however, was not pierced, nor nearly so, for

the point rebated, and repell’d the wound.

the point of the spear struck against the silver and was turned

encumber’d with the dart, atrides stands,

aside as though it had been lead: king agamemnon caught it from

till, grasp’d with force, he wrench’d it from his hands;

his hand, and drew it towards him with the fury of a lion; he

at once his weighty sword discharged a wound

then drew his sword, and killed iphidamas by striking him on the

full on his neck, that fell’d him to the ground.

neck.

stretch’d in the dust the unhappy warrior lies,
and sleep eternal seals his swimming eyes.
oh worthy better fate!
oh early slain!

so there the poor fellow lay, sleeping a sleep as it were

thy country’s friend; and virtuous, though in vain!
no more the youth shall join his consort’s side,

of bronze, killed in the defence of his fellow-citizens, far from

at once a virgin, and at once a bride!
no more with presents her embraces meet,

his wedded wife, of whom he had had no joy though he had given

or lay the spoils of conquest at her feet,
on whom his passion, lavish of his store,

much for her: he had given a hundred head of cattle down, and had

bestow’d so much, and vainly promised more!

promised later on to give a thousand sheep and goats mixed, from

unwept, uncover’d, on the plain he lay,

the countless flocks of which he was possessed.
agamemnon son of

while the proud victor bore his arms away.

atreus then despoiled him, and carried off his armour into the

coon, antenor’s eldest hope, was nigh:

host of the achaeans.
when noble coon, antenor’s eldest son, saw this, sore indeed were

tears, at the sight, came starting from his eye,
while pierced with grief the much-loved youth he view’d,

his eyes at the sight of his fallen brother.

and the pale features now deform’d with blood.

unseen by agamemnon

then, with his spear, unseen, his time he took,
aim’d at the king, and near his elbow strook.

he got beside him, spear in hand, and wounded him in the middle

the thrilling steel transpierced the brawny part,

of his arm below the elbow, the point of the spear going right

and through his arm stood forth the barbed dart.

through the arm.

surprised the monarch feels, yet void of fear

on coon rushes with his lifted spear:

grasped his spear that flew as fleet as the wind, and sprang upon

prone on his brother’s bleeding breast he lay,

through the press of men under cover of his shield: he then cut

the monarch’s falchion lopp’d his head away:

off his head, standing over the body of iphidamas.

the social shades the same dark journey go,

sons of antenor meet their fate at the hands of the son of

and join each other in the realms below.

atreus, and go down into the house of hades.

the vengeful victor rages round the fields,

as long as the blood still welled warm from his wound agamemnon

with every weapon art or fury yields:
by the long lance, the sword, or ponderous stone,
whole ranks are broken, and whole troops o’erthrown.

went about attacking the ranks of the enemy with spear and sword

this, while yet warm distill’d the purple flood;
but when the wound grew stiff with clotted blood,

and with great handfuls of stone, but when the blood had ceased

then grinding tortures his strong bosom rend,

to flow and the wound grew dry, the pain became great.

less keen those darts the fierce ilythiae send:

as the

(the powers that cause the teeming matron’s throes,

sad mothers of unutterable woes!

)

atreus.

stung with the smart, all-panting with the pain,

he sprang on to his chariot, and bade his charioteer

he mounts the car, and gives his squire the rein;

drive to the ships, for he was in great agony.

then with a voice which fury made more strong,

with a loud clear

and pain augmented, thus exhorts the throng:
“o friends!
o greeks!

assert your honours won;
proceed, and finish what this arm begun:
lo!
angry jove forbids your chief to stay,

counsellors of the argives, defend the ships yourselves, for jove

and envies half the glories of the day.

has not suffered me to fight the whole day through against the

”

trojans.
”

he said: the driver whirls his lengthful thong;

with this the charioteer turned his horses towards the ships, and

the horses fly; the chariot smokes along.

they flew forward nothing loth.

clouds from their nostrils the fierce coursers blow,

their chests were white with foam

and from their sides the foam descends in snow;

and their bellies with dust, as they drew the wounded king out of

the battle.

the wounded monarch at his tent they place.
no sooner hector saw the king retired,

when hector saw agamemnon quit the field, he shouted to the

but thus his trojans and his aids he fired:
“hear, all ye dardan, all ye lycian race!

trojans and lycians saying, “trojans, lycians, and dardanian

famed in close fight, and dreadful face to face:
now call to mind your ancient trophies won,

warriors, be men, my friends, and acquit yourselves in battle

your great forefathers’ virtues, and your own.
behold, the general flies!
deserts his powers!
lo, jove himself declares the conquest ours!

bravely; their best man has left them, and jove has vouchsafed me

now on yon ranks impel your foaming steeds;

a great triumph; charge the foe with your chariots that you may

and, sure of glory, dare immortal deeds.

win still greater glory.

”

”

with words like these the fiery chief alarms
his fainting host, and every bosom warms.

with these words he put heart and soul into them all, and as a

as the bold hunter cheers his hounds to tear
the brindled lion, or the tusky bear:

huntsman hounds his dogs on against a lion or wild boar, even so

with voice and hand provokes their doubting heart,
and springs the foremost with his lifted dart:
so godlike hector prompts his troops to dare;

did hector, peer of mars, hound the proud trojans on against the

nor prompts alone, but leads himself the war.

achaeans.

on the black body of the foe he pours;

full of hope he plunged in among the foremost, and fell

as from the cloud’s deep bosom, swell’d with showers,

on the fight like some fierce tempest that swoops down upon the

a sudden storm the purple ocean sweeps,
drives the wild waves, and tosses all the deeps.

sea, and lashes its deep blue waters into fury.

say, muse!

what, then is the full tale of those whom hector son of priam

when jove the trojan’s glory crown’d,
beneath his arm what heroes bit the ground?

killed in the hour of triumph which jove then vouchsafed him?

assaeus, dolops, and autonous died,

first asaeus, autonous, and opites; dolops son of clytius,
opheltius and agelaus; aesymnus, orus and hipponous steadfast in

opites next was added to their side;
then brave hipponous, famed in many a fight,
opheltius, orus, sunk to endless night;
æsymnus, agelaus; all chiefs of name;

battle; these chieftains of the achaeans did hector slay, and

the rest were vulgar deaths unknown to fame.

then he fell upon the rank and file.

as when a western whirlwind, charged with storms,

as when the west wind

dispels the gather’d clouds that notus forms:

hustles the clouds of the white south and beats them down with

the gust continued, violent and strong,

the fierceness of its fury—the waves of the sea roll high, and

rolls sable clouds in heaps on heaps along;
now to the skies the foaming billows rears,

the spray is flung aloft in the rage of the wandering wind—even

now breaks the surge, and wide the bottom bares:
thus, raging hector, with resistless hands,

so thick were the heads of them that fell by the hand of hector.

o’erturns, confounds, and scatters all their bands.
now the last ruin the whole host appals;

all had then been lost and no help for it, and the achaeans would

now greece had trembled in her wooden walls;

have fled pell-mell to their ships, had not ulysses cried out to

but wise ulysses call’d tydides forth,
his soul rekindled, and awaked his worth.

diomed, “son of tydeus, what has happened to us that we thus

“and stand we deedless, o eternal shame!

forget our prowess?
come, my good fellow, stand by my side and

till hector’s arm involve the ships in flame?
haste, let us join, and combat side by side.

help me, we shall be shamed for ever if hector takes the ships.

”

”

the warrior thus, and thus the friend replied:
“no martial toil i shun, no danger fear;
let hector come; i wait his fury here.

and diomed answered, “come what may, i will stand firm; but we

but jove with conquest crowns the trojan train:

shall have scant joy of it, for jove is minded to give victory to

and, jove our foe, all human force is vain.

the trojans rather than to us.

”

”

he sigh’d; but, sighing, raised his vengeful steel,
and from his car the proud thymbraeus fell:

with these words he struck thymbraeus from his chariot to the

molion, the charioteer, pursued his lord,

ground, smiting him in the left breast with his spear, while

his death ennobled by ulysses’ sword.

ulysses killed molion who was his squire.

there slain, they left them in eternal night,

these they let lie, now

that they had stopped their fighting; the two heroes then went on

so two wild boars outstrip the following hounds,

and rend the hounds that hunt them.

then swift revert, and wounds return for wounds.

thus did they turn upon the

had warn’d his children from the trojan field.

they rush’d to fight, and perish’d on the plain;

would not obey him, for fate lured them to their fall.

their breasts no more the vital spirit warms;

while hector rose, recover’d from the trance,

the greek pursues him, and exults aloud:

but diomed made at him with his spear and said, “dog, you have

“once more thank phœbus for thy forfeit breath,

again got away though death was close on your heels.

or thank that swiftness which outstrips the death.

phoebus

well by apollo are thy prayers repaid,
and oft that partial power has lent his aid.

apollo, to whom i ween you pray ere you go into battle, has again

”

the laughing trojan, with a joyful spring.
